{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} '''AbioCor''' was a total [[artificial heart]] (TAH) developed by the [[Massachusetts]]-based company [[AbioMed]]. It was fully implantable within a patient, due to a combination of advances in miniaturization, biosensors, [[plastics]] and energy transfer. The AbioCor ran on a [[Rechargeable battery|rechargeable source of power]]. The internal battery was charged by a [[transcutaneous energy transmission]] (TET) system, meaning that no wires or tubes penetrated the skin, reducing the risk of infection. However, because of its size, this heart was only compatible with men who had a large frame. It had a product life expectancy of 18 months.<ref name="HN_NMP188">{{cite web |url=https://www.healthnet.com/static/general/unprotected/pdfs/national/policies/TotalArtificialHeart.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Medical Policy - NMP188 |publisher=HealthNet |pages=17 |date=September 2015 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="Regence52">{{cite web |url=http://blue.regence.com/trgmedpol/surgery/sur52.pdf |format=PDF |title=Medical Policy Manual - Policy No: 52 |publisher=Regence |pages=22 |date=December 2015 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="THIAbioCor">{{cite web |url=http://www.texasheart.org/Research/Devices/abiocor.cfm |title=Heart Assist Devices - AbioCor Implantable |publisher=Texas Heart Institute |accessdate=15 March 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307073407/http://www.texasheart.org/research/devices/abiocor.cfm |archive-date=March 7, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="AMAbioCorArch07">{{cite web |url=http://www.abiomed.com/products/product_details.cfm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070521005214/http://www.abiomed.com/products/product_details.cfm |title=Product Details |publisher=AbioMed |date=2007 |archivedate=May 21, 2007 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="DowlingCurrent01">{{cite journal |title=Current status of the AbioCor implantable replacement heart |journal=The Annals of Thoracic Surgery |author =Dowling, R.D. |author2 =Etoch, S.W. |author3 =Stevens, K.A. |author4 =Johnson, A.C. |author5 =Gray Jr., L.A. |volume=71 |issue=3 |pages=S147–S149 |year=2001 |doi=10.1016/S0003-4975(00)02615-1 |pmid=11265850}}</ref>
AbioCor was surgically introduced into 15 total patients, 14 of them during a clinical trial and one after FDA approval. However, due to insufficient evidence of its efficacy, AbioMed abandoned further development of the product.<ref name="LeprinceTotal15">{{cite web |url=http://www.eacts.org/media/245551/dailynews6oct15.pdf |format=PDF |title=Total artificial heart: What's new? |author=Leprince, P. |work=Daily News - EACTS |page=7 |publisher=European Association for Cardio-Thoracic Surgery |date=6 October 2015 |accessdate=15 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315225303/http://www.eacts.org/media/245551/dailynews6oct15.pdf |archivedate=March 15, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="PalominoTheHeart15">{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/11/4/9665902/artificial-heart-transplant-cedars-sinai-clinical-trials |title=The Heart is Just a Pump: Inside the 50-year quest to build a mechanical organ |author =Palomino, J. |editor=Lopatto, E. |editor2=Zelenko, M. |work=The Verge |publisher=[[Vox Media, Inc.]] |date=4 November 2015 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="SC7Things14">{{cite web |url=http://www.syncardia.com/2014-multimedia-releases/7-things-about-artificial-hearts-that-you-should-know/itemid-1715.html |title=7 Things About Artificial Hearts That You Should Know |publisher=SynCardia Systems, Inc. |date=12 September 2014 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref>
==History== AbioMed, Inc. began development of the AbioCor device in the 1990s, beginning animal studies in 1998 in preparation to demonstrate readiness for formal clinical trials in humans.<ref name="DowlingCurrent01" /> On January 30, 2001, the FDA granted AbioMed an investigational device exemption (IDE) for implantation into humans via a clinical trial.<ref name="CastellucciAbiomed01">{{cite web |url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/786770 |title=Abiomed gets FDA approval to implant total artificial heart in humans |author =Castellucci, L. |work=Medscape |publisher=Medscape, Inc. |date=30 January 2001 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> This opened the door for the first implantation of the AbioCor into [[Robert Tools]] on July 2, 2001. He lived for 151 days before having a fatal [[cerebrovascular accident]].<ref name="THIAbioCor" /><ref name="AMAbioCorReplaceArch07">{{cite web |url=http://www.abiomed.com/products/heart_replacement.cfm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070615022011/http://www.abiomed.com/products/heart_replacement.cfm |title=Heart Replacement |publisher=AbioMed |date=2007 |archivedate=June 15, 2007 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="HamiltonAbioCor01">{{cite web |url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1936165_1936238,00.html |title=Abiocor Artificial Heart |author =Hamilton, A. |work=Time - Best Inventions of 2001 |publisher=Time, Inc. |date=19 November 2001 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> Time magazine awarded the AbioCor its Invention of the Year award in late 2001.<ref name="HamiltonAbioCor01" />
The second patient, Tom Christerson, who was given less than a 20 percent chance of surviving 30 days at the time of his surgery, lived for 512 days after receiving the AbioCor, dying on February 7, 2003 due to the wearing out of an internal membrane of the AbioCor.<ref name="IAHPTom03">{{cite web |url=http://www.heartpioneers.com/releases/020703.html |title=Tom Christerson, World's Second Artificial Heart Patient, Passes Away February 7, 2003 |publisher=The Implantable Artificial Heart Project |date=7 February 2003 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> An additional 12 patients had the device implanted into 2004, resulting in an average life span of less than five months among all 14 patients. In some cases the device extended survival by several months, allowing the patients to spend valuable time with family and friends. In two cases, the device extended survival by 10 and 17 months respectively, and one patient was discharged from the hospital to go home. For a patient to be eligible for implantation with the AbioCor, the person must have had severe [[heart failure]] (with failure of both [[ventricle (heart)|ventricle]]s) and had to be likely to die within two weeks without [[heart transplantation|transplantation]].<ref name="HN_NMP188" /><ref name="Regence52" />
Though the device was initially rejected by FDA Circulatory System Devices Panel in 2005 for [[Humanitarian Device Exemption]] (HDE) status,<ref name="HN_NMP188" /> it was eventually approved by the [[Food and Drug Administration]] on September 5, 2006 for HDE status.<ref name="IAHPAbiomed06">{{cite web |url=http://www.heartpioneers.com/releases/090506.html |title=Abiomed Receives FDA Approval of The AbioCor, The World's First Completely Self-Contained, Implantable Artificial Heart |publisher=The Implantable Artificial Heart Project |date=5 September 2006 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> However, only one patient received the AbioCor after approval, a "76-year-old man with congestive heart failure, who did not qualify for a heart transplant."<ref name="RothmanSurgeons09">{{cite web |url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2009/06/first_artificial_heart_implant.html |title=Surgeons perform first artificial heart implant in New Jersey |author =Rothman, C. |work=NJ.com |publisher=New Jersey On-Line, LLC |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref>
In August 2012, key AbioCor researcher and developer David Lederman died from pancreatic cancer.<ref name="HevesiDavid12">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/29/health/research/david-lederman-pioneer-of-artificial-heart-dies-at-68.html |title=David Lederman, Pioneer of Artificial Heart, Dies at 68 |author =Hevesi, D. |work=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |date=28 August 2012 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref>
The company also had plans to improve the AbioCor with a second version based upon the AbioCor ventricles and the [[Penn State]] energy converter. It was expected to last for five years, more than triple the life expectancy of AbioCor. The company stated it would be 30 percent smaller than the original model, and it could be implanted in smaller men and women. Additional modifications were planned to reduce the patient's risk of stroke, which was a concern of the FDA.<ref name="AMAbioCorReplaceArch07" /><ref name="AbioCorFAQ">{{cite web |url=http://www.abiomed.com/assets/2010/11/AbioCor-FAQ-FINAL.pdf |format=PDF |title=AbioCor: Frequently Asked Questions |pages=2 |publisher=AbioMed, Inc. |date=November 2010 |accessdate=15 March 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317223307/http://www.abiomed.com/assets/2010/11/AbioCor-FAQ-FINAL.pdf |archive-date=March 17, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> {{As of|March 2016}}, AbioCor II has not come to fruition, however. Additionally, the AbioCor product has been removed from the AbioMed website, with several news agencies reporting in 2015 that the company had quietly abandoned further development of the device.<ref name="LeprinceTotal15" /><ref name="PalominoTheHeart15" />
==In popular culture== The AbioCor heart is featured in the 2009 film ''[[Crank: High Voltage]]'', when it is transplanted into the main character [[Chev Chelios]]'s ([[Jason Statham]]) chest after he had been abducted by Chinese mobsters in the very beginning of the movie. However, the heart depicted in the film has a much lower battery life but gives Chev [[superhuman]] athleticism when fully charged (for dramatic purposes).<ref name="PSCrank">{{cite web |url=http://www.siol.net/tv/naj_gledano/2012/08/adrenalin_2.aspx |title=Adrenalin 2: Visoka napetost (Crank: High Voltage) |work=PlanetSiol.net |publisher=TSmedia, medijske vsebine in storitve, d.o.o. |date=7 August 2012 |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> The model of the heart in the movie is called AviCor.

{{Infobox Person | name = Alice Ann Cornwell | image = Alice Ann Cornwell in 1889.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1 January 1852 | birth_place = [[West Ham]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1932|01|07|1852|01|01||df=yes}} | death_place = [[Hove]] | death_cause = | residence = | other_names = | known_for = | education = [[Royal Academy of Music]] | employer = | occupation = mine and newspaper owner | spouse = {{Plainlist| * John Whiteman * "Phil" Robinson }} | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = | nationality = [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] }}
'''Alice Ann Cornwell''' or '''Alice Whiteman''' or '''Alice Robinson''' (1 January 1852 – 7 January 1932) was a [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]] goldmining industrialist and newspaper proprietor. She made her fortune from gold and floated her company on the London Stock Exchange. She was a confident business person investing in several companies including owning the [[Sunday Times]]
==Life== Cornwell was born in [[West Ham]] in 1852 to Jemima and [[George Cornwell]]. She and her family emigrated to New Zealand when she was nine.<ref name=cornodnb/> Her father was an engineer.
Her first marriage was with the much older John Whiteman. He was a politician and publican. This marriage resulted in a legal separation before she left for England, but it was not ended until Whiteman died.
Her fortune was made when she returned from England after education at the [[Royal Academy of Music]] to Australia. Her father was a successful engineer who was then prospecting but he was not making a profit. Cornwell studied his ground and convinced others that a major find lay beneath his land. Shafts were created where she had indicated and gold was reputedly found within 30 centimetres of where she had said it would be.<ref name=cornodnb>Griffiths, D. (2004-09-23). Cornwell [other married names Whiteman, Robinson], Alice Ann (1852–1932), gold-mining industrialist and newspaper proprietor. Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Retrieved 9 Dec. 2017, see [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-56583 link]</ref>
In 1886 she returned to London as a reputed millionaire, although this may have been an exaggeration. Despite not being able to enter London's club's because of her gender she floated the "Midas Mine" on the London Stock Exchange. Moreover she also created the British and Australian Mining Trust and Investment Company. The purpose of this company was to allow people to invest money directly in Australian mines.<ref name="aus">{{Cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/review/alice-cornwell-fergus-hume-on-our-mysterious-madame-midas/news-story/0ab201c802e04c7db743c926183d516a|title=Woman with the golden touch|date=2017-01-27|access-date=2017-12-10}}</ref>
Cornwell bought the [[Sunday Times]] in 1887 from Colonel [[George FitzGeorge]] who an illegitimate member of the Royal Family.<ref name="Negev2012">{{cite book|author=Eilat Negev|title=The First Lady of Fleet Street: The Life, Fortune and Tragedy of Rachel Beer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LvitAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT126|date=6 September 2012|publisher=Biteback Publishing|isbn=978-1-84954-460-3|pages=126–}}</ref> Her purpose was promote her new company and it was a gift to her lover Frederick Stannard (‘Phil’) Robinson.<ref name=cornodnb/> In 1888 her friend [[Fergus Hume]] wrote a novel, "Madame Midas" about a "Mrs Villiers" which was obviously based on Cornwell.<ref name="aus"/>
Cornwell sold the "Sunday Times" in 1893 to Frederick Beer, who already owned ''[[The Observer|Observer]]''. Beer appointed his wife, [[Rachel Beer|Rachel Sassoon Beer]], as editor.<ref>{{cite book|title= The Pearl of Days|author=Hobson, Harold, Knightley, Phillip and Russell, Leonard|year=1972|publisher=Hamish Hamilton|isbn=0 241 02266 5 |page=52}}</ref>
Cornwell's estranged first husband died in 1893<ref>[http://earlyphotographers.blogspot.co.uk/2011/03/bardwell-william-h.html Bush Advocate cited by earlyphotographers], Volume IX, Issue 729, 19 January 1893, Page 2 </ref> and she married Robinson in 1894.<ref name=cornodnb/>
Cornwell died in 1932 in [[Hove]].<ref name=cornodnb/>

Eng. | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | country = | frequency = 18/year | history = 1981-present | openaccess = | license = | impact = 3.444 | impact-year = 2016 | website = http://www.journals.elsevier.com/applied-thermal-engineering/ | link1 = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/13594311 | link1-name = Online access | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = 33420600 | LCCN = 96648165 | CODEN = ATENFT | ISSN = 1359-4311 | eISSN = }} '''''Applied Thermal Engineering''''' is a [[peer-reviewed]] [[scientific journal]] publishing original articles concerning all aspects of the [[thermal engineering]] of advanced processes, including process integration, intensification, and development, together with the application of thermal equipment in conventional process plant, which includes its use for heat recovery. The current [[editor-in-chief]] is T. S. Zhao.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journals.elsevier.com/applied-thermal-engineering/editorial-board/ |title=Applied Thermal Engineering: Editorial Board |publisher=Elsevier}}</ref> The journal was established in 1981 as ''Journal of Heat Recovery Systems'' and renamed to ''Heat Recovery Systems and CHP'' in 1987. It obtained its current title in 1996.
According to the ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]'', the journal has a 2017 [[impact factor]] of 3.771.<ref name=WoS>{{cite book |year=2016 |chapter=Applied Thermal Engineering |title=2013 [[Journal Citation Reports]] |publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] |edition=Science |series=[[Web of Science]]}}</ref> According to SCOPUS, the journal's h-index is 121<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scimagojr.com/journalsearch.php?q=13688&tip=sid|title=Applied Thermal Engineering|website=www.scimagojr.com|access-date=2018-08-18}}</ref>.

[[File:Autographic Register.jpg|thumb|right|Autographic Register - National Cash Register Company, 1898]] An '''Autographic Register''' is a business machine invented in 1883 by James C. Shoup. The device consisted two separate rolls of paper interleaved with [[carbon paper]]. Usually one or both of the rolls would be preprinted with form information. To operate the machine the user would write, for example, a sales receipt and the machine automatically produced a copy. The crank on the machine ejected the records and moved a blank form into view. The original receipt produced would go to the user and the copy was filed.<ref name=BusRef>{{cite web|title=Standard Register Co.|url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/4/Standard-Register-Co.html|website=Reference for Business|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref> Shoup founded the Autographic Register Company in [[Hoboken, NJ]] to manufacture his invention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hoboken.pastperfectonline.com/bysearchterm?keyword=Autographic+Register+Company|website=Hoboken Historical Museum Online Collections Database|title=Autographic Register Company|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref>
The Autographic Register was an advance over use of separate forms and carbon paper as it guaranteed that the copy was made and kept the forms in relative alignment. A number of advancements were soon made, including the use of sprocket-fed paper, invented by Theodore Schirmer. This helped avoid slippage and misalignment of forms, allowing more copies to be produced simultaneously. In 1912 Schirmer founded the [[Standard Register Industrial|Standard Register Company]] in [[Dayton, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Standard Register|title=100 Years of Innovation|url=http://media.standardregister.com/standard-register/docs/company/Centennial-Whitepaper.pdf|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref>
The invention of sprocket-fed paper later found use in computer printers.
Although the Autographic Register has been largely replaced by newer technology it remains in use as of 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Portable Register - Plastic Register for 4 x 6 Forms|url=https://www.deluxe.com/shopdeluxe/pd/portable-register-plastic-register-for-4-x-6-forms/_/A-D924|website=Deluxe Enterprise Operations|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref>

{{multiple image |align= |direction= vertical |header= Most prominent billionaires in the race<ref name=Fortune-2016-11-15>{{cite news |url= http://fortune.com/2016/11/15/richard-branson-elon-musk-jeff-bezos/ |title= What Billionaire Richard Branson Thinks of Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk |work= Fortune |publisher= Time |date= 15 November 2016 |author= Polina Marinova }}</ref> |image1= Richard Branson UN Conference on Sustainable Development 2012.jpg |caption1= Richard Branson <ref name=Fortune-2016-11-15/> |image2= Elon Musk - The Summit 2013.jpg |caption2= Elon Musk <ref name=Fortune-2016-11-15/> |image3= Jeff Bezos 2005.jpg |caption3= Jeff Bezos <ref name=Fortune-2016-11-15/> }} The '''billionaire space race'''<ref name=DailyBeast-2016-06-19/><ref name=Bloomberg-2015-04-13>{{cite news |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-13/allen-and-branson-best-musk-as-the-billionaire-space-race-takes-off |title= Allen and Branson Best Musk as the Billionaire Space Race Takes Off |author= Robert Lafranco |date= 13 April 2015 |publisher= Bloomberg }}</ref><ref name=TheWeek-2016-09-17>{{cite news |url= http://theweek.com/articles/648995/great-billionaire-space-race |title= The great billionaire space race |author= Charles W. Luzier |work= Reuters |publisher= The Week |date= 17 September 2016 }}</ref> is the intense [[Space launch market competition|rivalry]] in [[NewSpace]] by recent space entrepreneurs, who entered the [[space industry]] as [[billionaire]]s from other industries, particularly computing.<ref name=Spectator-2016-May>{{cite magazine |url= http://www.spectator.co.uk/2016/05/watch-this-space-why-billionaires-are-launching-extraterrestrial-adventures/ |title= Watch this space: why billionaires are launching extraterrestrial adventures |author= Matthew Lynn |date= May 2016 |magazine= The Spectator }}</ref><ref name=WashPost-2016-08-19>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/the-billionaire-space-barons-and-the-next-giant-leap/2016/08/19/795a4012-6307-11e6-8b27-bb8ba39497a2_story.html |title= The inside story of how billionaires are racing to take you to outer space |author= Christian Davenport |date= 19 August 2016 |publisher= Washington Post }}</ref> This private industry [[space race]] of the 21st century involves [[sounding rocket]]s to the [[ignorosphere]] ([[mesosphere]] and [[thermosphere]]), orbital launch rockets, and suborbital tourist [[spaceflight]]s.<ref name="ISBN 1594206724"/>
Amongst the billionaires entering into New Space, are: * Russian billionarie [[Yuri Milner]], backing the [[Breakthrough Starshot]] project for an interstellar probe.<ref name=Spectator-2016-May/> * South-African-Canadian-American billionaire [[Elon Musk]],<ref name=Bloomberg-2015-04-13/><ref name=DailyMail-2016-08-01/> behind [[SpaceX]] and a project to colonize Mars. <ref name=TheWeek-2016-09-17/><ref name=Fortune-2016-11-15/> * American billionaire [[Jeff Bezos]],<ref name=DailyMail-2016-08-01/> behind [[Blue Origin]] and establishing a true industrial base in space. <ref name=TheWeek-2016-09-17/><ref name=DailyMail-2016-08-01/><ref name=DailyBeast-2016-06-19/><ref name=Fortune-2016-11-15/> * American billionaire [[Paul G. Allen]],<ref name=Bloomberg-2015-04-13/><ref name=DailyMail-2016-08-01/> behind [[Vulcan Aerospace]] and reducing the cost to launch payload to orbit. <ref name=TheWeek-2016-09-17/><ref name=Spectator-2016-May/> * British billionaire [[Richard Branson]],<ref name=Bloomberg-2015-04-13/><ref name=DailyMail-2016-08-01/> behind [[Virgin Galactic]]; and [[space tourism]], low cost small orbital launchers, and intercontinental suborbital transit. <ref name=TheWeek-2016-09-17/><ref name=DailyMail-2016-08-01/><ref name=DailyBeast-2016-06-19/><ref name=Fortune-2016-11-15/>
==Background== The groundwork for the billionaire space race and [[NewSpace]] was arguably laid by [[Peter Diamandis]], an American entrepreneur. In the 1980s, he founded an American national student space society, the [[Students for the Exploration and Development of Space]] (SEDS). Later, [[Jeff Bezos]] became a chapter president of SEDS. In the 1990s, Diamandis, dissolute with the state of space development, decided to spur it on and spark the suborbital space tourism market, by initiating a prize, the [[X Prize]]. This led to [[Paul Allen]] becoming involved in the competition, creating the [[Scaled Composites Tier One]] platform of [[SpaceShipOne]] and [[White Knight One]] which won the [[Ansari X-Prize]] in the 2000s. The technology of the winning entrant was then licensed by [[Richard Branson]]'s [[Virgin Group]] as a basis to found [[Virgin Galactic]]. The base techniques of Tier One also form the basis for [[Stratolaunch Systems]] of [[Vulcan Aerospace]].<ref name=WashPost-2016-09-19>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/the-billionaire-space-barons-and-the-next-giant-leap/2016/08/19/795a4012-6307-11e6-8b27-bb8ba39497a2_story.html |title= The renegade whose dream started the latest space race |author= Vivek Wadhwa |date= 19 September 2016 |publisher= Washington Post }}</ref><ref name="ISBN 1594206724">{{cite book |title= How to Make a Spaceship: A Band of Renegades, an Epic Race, and the Birth of Private Spaceflight |author= Julian Guthrie |date= 2016 |isbn= 978-1594206726 }}</ref> The billionaire space race shows the aims of billionaires extend beyond just fulfilling government contracts, with their own gilding of the [[space age]], in extending capabilities and their own luster. Elon Musk has expressed excitement for a new space race.<ref name=Guardian-2018-02-09>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/09/new-space-race-billionaires-elon-musk-jeff-bezos |title= The new space race: how billionaires launched the next era of exploration |author= Alan Yuhas |date= 9 February 2018 |publisher= The Guardian }}</ref>.
==Rivalries== {{expand section|date=April 2017}}
===SpaceX vs Blue Origin=== [[SpaceX]] and [[Blue Origin]] have had a long history of conflict.<ref name=TheWeek-2016-09-17/><ref name=WashPost-2016-08-19/> There is a vision of a hare versus a tortoise, for the two respectively, from Blue Origin's standpoint.<ref name=INverse-2016-04-15>{{cite news |url= https://www.inverse.com/article/14059-the-mystery-behind-blue-origin-s-turtle-friendly-coat-of-arms |title= The Mystery Behind Blue Origin's Turtle-Friendly Coat of Arms |author= Lauren J. Young |date= 15 April 2016 |publisher= inVERSE }}</ref> Blue Origin and SpaceX have had dueling press releases that compete with each other's announcements and events.<ref name=Bloomberg-2017-03-08>{{cite news |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-08/spacex-reflying-rocket-this-month-in-step-toward-cheap-launches |title= SpaceX Will Launch Its First Reused Rocket Later This Month |author= Dana Hull |date= 8 March 2017 |publisher= Bloomberg }}</ref><ref name=Gizmodo-2017-03-31>{{cite news |url= https://gizmodo.com/is-blue-origins-tourist-capsule-sexier-than-spacexs-1793906303 |title= Is Blue Origin's Tourist Capsule Sexier Than SpaceX's? |author= Rae Paoletta |date= 31 March 2017 |publisher= Gizmodo }}</ref>
SpaceX and Blue Origin battled for the right to lease [[Kennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39|SLC 39A]], the rocket launch platform that was used to launch the Apollo moon missions. SpaceX won the lease in 2013, but Blue Origin filed suit in court against that. It is currently in the hands of SpaceX, while Blue Origin rented [[SLC 36]] instead.<ref name=WashPost-2016-08-19/>
SpaceX filed suit against Blue Origin to invalidate their patent on landing rockets aboard ships at sea. They won their court fight in 2014. SpaceX had been attempting to land rockets at sea since 2014, finally succeeding in 2016, before Blue Origin ever even built a sea-going platform to land rockets onto.<ref name=WashPost-2016-08-19/>
SpaceX and Blue Origin got into a Twitter battle about the meaning of a used rocket, landed rocket, spacerocket, at the end of 2015, when [[New Shepard]] successfully landed, after a suborbital jaunt into space. SpaceX had previously launched and landed its [[SpaceX Grasshopper|Grasshopper]] rocket multiple times without reaching space. Then SpaceX landed a [[Falcon 9]] first stage, which had been used to launch a satellite into orbit, prompting more Twitter battle at the start of 2016.<ref name=WashPost-2016-08-19/>
In late 2016, Blue Origin announced the [[New Glenn]], directly competing against SpaceX's [[Falcon Heavy]], with a larger rocket but lower payload.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.cnet.com/news/new-glenn-rocket-from-jeff-bezos-blue-origin-to-compete-with-spacex/ |title= Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin to take on SpaceX with supersized rocket New Glenn |author= Eric Mack |date= 12 September 2016 |publisher= cNet news }}</ref>
At the 2016 [[International Astronautical Congress]] in Guadalajara, Mexico, Blue Origin President Rob Meyerson elaborated on the Bezos vision previously outlined in the New Glenn announcement. The Blue Origin [[New Armstrong]] would be similar in function to the SpaceX [[Interplanetary Transport System]] that Elon Musk unveiled at the same conference.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.geekwire.com/2016/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-space-mars-moon/ |title= Jeff Bezos’ Blue Origin space venture sets its sights on trips to Mars and the moon |author= Alan Boyle |date= 27 September 2016 |publisher= GeekWire }}</ref>
===Blue Origin vs Virgin Galactic=== [[Blue Origin]] and [[Virgin Galactic]] are in the same market, [[suborbital]] [[space tourism]], with [[New Shepard]] and [[SpaceShipTwo]] ([[Scaled Composites Tier 1b|Tier 1b]]), respectively. They are in a race to be first to launch paying customers on short spaceshots, with rival technological philosophies of [[space capsule]]s and [[spaceplane]]s, respectively<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.sciencealert.com/virgin-galactic-just-got-awarded-their-operating-license |title= Virgin Galactic is finally licensed to take tourists into space |author= Josh Hrala |date= 4 August 2016 |publisher= Science Alert }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://money.cnn.com/2016/06/19/news/companies/blue-origin-rocket-landing-fourth-mission/ |title= Blue Origin successfully crash tests space-tourism capsule |author= Jackie Wattles |date= 20 June 2016 |publisher= CNN Money }}</ref><ref name=DailyMail-2016-08-01>{{cite news |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3718927/Virgin-Galactic-space-race-FAA-gives-Richard-Branson-s-firm-operating-license-space-tourism.html |title= Virgin Galactic is back in the space race: FAA gives Richard Branson's firm operating license for space tourism |author= Mark Prigg |date= 1 August 2016 |publisher= Daily Mail (London) }}</ref><ref name=DailyBeast-2016-06-19>{{cite news |url= http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/06/19/jeff-bezos-ready-to-beat-richard-branson-in-the-billionaire-space-race.html |title= Jeff Bezos Ready to Beat Richard Branson in the Billionaire Space Race |date= 19 June 2016 |author= Clive Irving |publisher= The Daily Beast }}</ref><ref name=Fortune-2016-11-15/>
===Virgin Galactic vs SpaceX=== [[Virgin Galactic]] and [[SpaceX]] support competing communications satellite constellations. Each would launch their satellites on their own launchers, [[LauncherOne]] and [[Falcon 9]]/[[Falcon Heavy]] respectively. The satellite systems would compete for the same market and same bandwidth and go head-to-head at the [[International Telecommunications Union|ITU]] for satellite frequency licenses.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://spacenews.com/spacex-opening-seattle-plant-to-build-4000-broadband-satellites/ |title= SpaceX To Build 4,000 Broadband Satellites in Seattle |author= Peter B. de Selding |date= 19 January 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.satellitetoday.com/launch/2016/04/27/launcherone-to-start-test-missions-in-2017/ |title= LauncherOne to Start Test Missions in 2017 |author= Caleb Henry |date= 27 April 2016 |publisher= Satellite Today |work= Via Satellite }}</ref>
===Stratolaunch vs Virgin Galactic=== [[Vulcan Aerospace]] subsidiary [[Stratolaunch Systems]] plans to air-launch satellite launcher rockets, the same profile as planned by [[Virgin Galactic]] for its [[LauncherOne]] operations. While LauncherOne is already under development and launch aircraft procured (once [[White Knight Two]], now 747 [[Cosmic Girl (airplane)|Cosmic Girl]]), the [[Scaled Composites]] "Roc" [[Scaled Composites Model 351|Model 351]] is still being developed and the rocket to mate to it has yet to be selected.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.csmonitor.com/Technology/2016/0620/Paul-Allen-vs.-Elon-Musk-a-different-approach-to-satellite-launches |title= Paul Allen vs. Elon Musk: a different approach to satellite launches |author= Max Lewontin |date= 20 June 2016 |publisher= Christian Science Monitor }}</ref>
==Impact on the space sector== The billionaire space race and the rise of Space 2.0 has impacted on "Old Space", the old space hands of the pre-existing aerospace sector. The disruptive forces of NewSpace may wash away some of the standing members of the community. In particular SpaceX and Blue Origin represent existential threats to the old boys club and staid storied enterprises of aerospace. SpaceX challenges all members of the old guard with the pricing of its launch vehicles, being lower than the previous low cost leader, the Chinese launch services. It greatly undercuts the monopolistic leader of the European and American space launch services sectors, respectively, [[ArianeSpace]] and [[United Launch Alliance]] (an alliance of [[Boeing]] and [[Lockheed Martin]]). The position of Blue Origin is that of a future threat. Both SpaceX and Blue Origin put forth reusable launch vehicles, forcing ULA and Ariane to design next generation rockets with partial reusability features to attempt to reduce costs to be competitive with the new twin threats, using the [[ULA Vulcan|Vulcan]] and [[Ariane 6]] respectively. Boeing has also fired shots across the bow of SpaceX (and others) in the race to Mars, intending to arrive first. Boeing and SpaceX both are exploring sub-orbital transport with hypersonic rocket transports, SpaceX basing it on reusable Falcon 9 technology, which would compete with transcontinental and transoceanic air travel.<ref name=Fortune-2016-10-26>{{cite news |url= http://fortune.com/spacex-ula-lockheed-boeing-rocket-race/ |title= The Great Rocket Race |author= Clay Dillow |date= 26 October 2016 |publisher= Fortune }}</ref><ref name=Wired-2011-04-18>{{cite news |url= https://www.wired.com/2011/04/china-wonders-about-spacexs-rock-bottom-prices/ |title= China Wonders About SpaceX’S Rock Bottom Prices |author= Jason Paur |date= 18 April 2011 |publisher= Wired }}</ref><ref name=SatLight-2011-05-04>{{cite news |url= http://satellite.tmcnet.com/topics/satellite/articles/171190-spacex-defends-its-cheaper-than-china-launchers-cost.htm |title= SpaceX Defends its 'Cheaper than China' Launchers, Cost Structure |author= Doug Mohney |publisher= Satellite Light |date= 4 May 2011 }}</ref><ref name=MotleyFool-2016-05-01>{{cite news |url= http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2016/03/01/could-europes-ariane-6-rocket-beat-spacexs.aspx |title= Could Europe's Ariane 6 Rocket Beat SpaceX's? |author= Rich Smith |date= 1 May 2016 |publisher= The Motley Fool }}</ref><ref name=CSMon-2016-10-10>{{cite news |url= http://www.csmonitor.com/Science/2016/1010/Did-Boeing-s-CEO-just-kick-off-a-billionaires-space-race |title= Did Boeing's CEO just kick off a billionaires' space race? |author= Ben Rosen |date= 10 October 2016 |publisher= Christian Science Monitor }}</ref><ref name=MotleyFool-2016-10-15>{{cite news |url= http://www.fool.com/investing/2016/10/15/boeing-boasts-well-beat-spacex-to-mars.aspx |title= Boeing Boasts: We'll Beat SpaceX to Mars! |author= Rich Smith |date= 15 October 2016 |publisher= Motley Fool }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Space Race|Cold War Space Race]]; between the U.S.A. and U.S.S.R.; leading to the Race to the Moon <!-- * [[Space Race II]]; between the U.S, Russia, China, for a manned presence in space --> <!-- * [[Space Race 2.0]]; between old space contractors of the mid-century, more recent ones of late-century from the Shuttle and ISS era, and NewSpace 21st century newcomers --> * [[Asian space race]]; between China, India, and Japan for space prestige * [[Space launch market competition]] * [[Commercialization of space]] * [[Mars race]]

'''Bram Lebo''' is a Canadian entrepreneur, media proprietor and business consultant.
Lebo studied law at the [[Osgoode Hall Law School]] and was called to the Ontario Bar in 1994.<ref>https://www.lsuc.on.ca/uploadedFiles/PDC/Archives/Call_to_the_Bar/1994-02%20programme.pdf</ref> That same year Lebo moved to the Netherlands where he completed his MBA and Master of Business Informatics from the [[Rotterdam School of Management]] at [[Erasmus University Rotterdam|Erasmus University]].<ref name=gravitas>[http://www.getgravitas.com/aboutus.html "About Us", Gravitas Business Architects]</ref>
In the mid-1990s, Lebo worked for [[DigiCash]], a pioneering [[electronic money|electronic currency]] corporation based in Amsterdam, followed by three years as a business developer and strategist for multinationals in Europe.<ref>[http://hsw-basel.ch/iwi/publications.nsf/6f29dfc9097efd0bc12572180036eb54/3bbe038ea9f8d3e6c125722e002922ee/$FILE/Ab_bm51.pdf Andrea Himmelspach, Alexander Runge, Petra Schubert, Hans-Dieter Zimmermann; ''Anforderungen an elektronische Zahlungssysteme''; October 1996; Universität St. Gallen - Hochschule für Wirtschafts-, Rechts- und Sozialwissenschaften (HSG)]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In 2000, Lebo founded [[Expatica]], an online newspaper for English-speakers living in Europe, based in Amsterdam with operations in four other countries. Expatica grew to become the most widely read English-language publication in Continental Europe, in any medium, rivaling major newspapers in readership.<ref name=gravitas/><ref>[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,214741,00.html "Expats of the world, unite!", ''Time'' magazine, March 8, 2002]</ref>
Lebo later returned to Canada and worked for the [[Government of Ontario]], and as of 2008 served as the Director of Marketing and Brand Development for [[ServiceOntario]], a [[Government of Ontario]] initiative to give Ontarians an easy, cost-effective way to access government services.<ref>[http://www.mgs.gov.on.ca/stdprodconsume/groups/content/@mgs/@aboutmin/documents/resourcelist/247936.pdf Organization chart, Ontario Ministry of Government and Consumer Services]</ref> In 2009 he co-founded Gravitas Business Architects.
In recent years Lebo has worked as a radio host at [[CKHA-FM|Canoe FM (CKHA)]], "the Voice of [[Haliburton County]]" in Ontario's "[[cottage country]]", hosting the shows "County Hot Seat" and "Half Facts".<ref>[https://archive.is/20130118164546/http://www.canoefm.com/program/122/Half_Facts_with_Bram_Lebo___Brigitte_Gall "Half Facts with Bram Lebo & Brigitte Gall", 100.9 Canoe FM]</ref>
Currently Lebo is publisher of and a columnist at [[The Highlander]] newspaper<ref>[http://haliburtonhighlander.ca/category/bram-lebo-2/ "Archives by category: Bram Lebo", Haliburton Highlander]</ref> and serves on the Board of the Haliburton Highlands Chamber of Commerce <ref>[http://www.haliburtonecho.ca/secondary_id/830?id=876 "Chamber of Commerce hears about impact of provincial pension plan", Angelica Ingram, Haliburton County ''Echo'', June 21, 2016]</ref>
==Books== Lebo authored ''The Law Students' Guide to Articling and Summer Positions in Canada '' ({{ISBN|0920722539}} (0-920722-53-9)).<ref>[http://www.abebooks.com/Lebo-Bram/author/11165866 ''The Law Students' Guide to Articling and Summer Positions in Canada'', ABE Books]</ref><ref>[http://www.bookfinder.com/author/bram-lebo/ ''The Law Students' Guide to Articling and Summer Positions in Canada'', BookFinder.com]</ref>

[[S&P 500|S&P 500 Component]] | location = [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]], [[Minnesota]], [[United States|USA]] | industry = [[Medical equipment]] | services = [[Medical technology]] | products = [[Medical devices]] | foundation = 1971 }} '''Cardiac Pacemakers, Inc.'''(CPI), doing business as Guidant Cardiac Rhythm Management, manufactured implantable cardiac rhythm management devices, such as [[pacemaker]]s and [[defibrillator]]s. It also sold insulin pumps controlled by microprocessors and various equipments to regulate heart rhythm. In addition, Cardiac Pacemakers, Inc. developed therapies for the treatment of irregular heartbeats. The company was founded in 1971 and is based in St. Paul, Minnesota. Cardiac Pacemakers, Inc. operates as a subsidiary of [[Boston Scientific Corporation]].{{cite web|website=investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=4223331|publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek}} ==Acquisition & Mergers== CPI was a highly successful start up venture, increasing sales from zero in 1972 to over $47 million and highly profitable when it was acquired by [[Eli Lilly and Company]] in 1978 for $127 million. During the 1970s, Lilly acquired other medical device companies including IVAC of San Diego, Physio Control of Redmond WA, and Advanced Cardiovascular Systems of Santa Clara, CA. These companies formed the core product/therapy areas of the Medical Devices Division of Eli Lilly and Company.{{cite web|title=Pioneers of the Medical Device Industry|website=www.mnhs.org/collections/medTech/org_cardiac_pacemakers.php|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society}} ==World's first use of the lithium battery== CPI designed and manufactured the worlds first pacemaker with a lithium anode and a lithium-iodide electrolyte solid-state battery. An improved heart pacer including the conventional combination of a pulse generator, electrode means, and electrode leads coupling the pulse generator to the electrodes, wherein the battery power source of the pulse generator is a solid-state battery with a lithium anode and a lithium-iodide electrolyte.(see [[Wilson Greatbatch]], ed.). The pacer structure is enclosed in a hermetically sealed metallic enclosure, with means being provided in the enclosure for passing electrode leads in sealed relationship therethrough. The outer surface of the casing is polished metal*, and is continuous in all areas. In certain instances, the continuity may be with the exception of the zone through which the external electrode leads pass.{{cite web|title=Metal-enclosed cardiac pacer with solid-state power source|website=www.google.com/patents/US3822707?dq=3822707|publisher=US3822707 A}} [[Image:CPI Pacemaker.jpg|thumb|World's first lithium battery powered pacemaker]] Lithium-iodide or lithium anode cells became the standard for future pacemaker designs. ==References== [[Category:Implants (medicine)]] [[Category:Embedded systems]] [[Category:American inventions]] [[Category:Cardiac electrophysiology]] [[Category:Biomedical engineering]]

In the [[Ecommerce|e-commerce]] industry, '''conversion as a service''' is a method of online [[conversion optimization]] that is a customized intersection of art and technology that combines [[analytics]], [[behavioral targeting]], [[software]], style, and business rules to exact success.<ref name="What Are Some Top Strategies For Conversion Optimization?">{{cite web|last=Johns|first=Andy|title=What Are Some Top Strategies For Conversion Optimization?|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/quora/2012/03/28/what-are-some-top-strategies-for-conversion-optimization/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> This approach advocates a holistic approach to achieve an improvement in [[Conversion rate|online conversion]].<ref name="Conversion Optimization In The New Marketing Landscape">{{cite web|last=Brinker|first=Scott|title=Conversion Optimization In The New Marketing Landscape|url=http://searchengineland.com/conversion-optimization-in-the-new-marketing-landscape-88234|accessdate=20 March 2012}}</ref>
Conversion as a Service (Caas) allows clients to take advantage of the accumulated expertise of a [[Vendor (supply chain)|vendor]], rather than either developing and maintaining the expertise in-house or [[outsourcing]] the expertise through a third-party services firm. Opting for vendor expertise ensures a knowledge base for the lifetime of the relationship and real-time program optimization.
CRO is a process of improving the performance of your website using user feedback and visitor analytics. There are some metrics on your website which you want to improve, normally called as key performance indicators. These factors can be improved via CRO. Most of the time these metrics are associated with acquisition of new customers, downloads, sign up’s etc.In short,it is a process of improving the percentage of passive visitors into valuable consumers.
In the process of CRO, what visitors are searching and looking while they surf your site is found out and that information to provide to them. Depending on what metrics you want to improve CRO may take varied forms.An example would be placing strong call to actions on a high traffic but under optimized page. In some cases, it refers to removal of unnecessary and complicated steps from conversion funnel which hinder conversions.
== Key Characteristics ==
=== Pay-For-Performance Models === Performance measurement is key to Conversion as a Service. In [[pay to play|pay-for-performance]] models, the success or failure of a solution is not based on whether providers successfully deploy software, but on whether or not the solution delivers desired measurable results. In this model, providers and clients align their efforts to meet a set of agreed-upon metrics that determine whether or not the relationship is valuable.<ref name="Are You Optimizing Your Website for Conversions?">{{cite web|last=Kilgore|first=Craig|title=Are You Optimizing Your Website for Conversions?|url=http://www.business2community.com/online-marketing/are-you-optimizing-your-website-for-conversions-0133423|accessdate=5 April 2012}}</ref>
In most cases, the metrics used in [[Electronic commerce|online commerce]] revolve around gains in incremental revenue directly attributable to a solution provider. The specific metric can vary, whether it is an increase in average order value, [[Upselling|up-sell]], or [[customer satisfaction]] or a decrease in cart abandonment or [[call center]] traffic, the solution provider must be able to demonstrate that an increase in revenue can be tied to the presence of their solution.
=== Goals === There are three goals for clarity in Pay-For-Performance Models:
;Transparency: Pay-for-performance models require a level of transparency on the part of the vendor to share with clients both the process for collecting the data and for measuring the results. Also, the calculations should be kept simple and the ability to inspect the data readily available.
;Alignment: Organizations often use metrics to define success for groups and individuals, to guide their activities, and to grade their performance. Similarly, vendors should be committed to meet the [[Strategic planning|business objectives]] of an organization through goals. In most pay-for-performance models, vendors define the metrics by which they will be graded. While this model forces vendors to perform, it does not guarantee that success will directly align with business needs. The models result from negotiations between vendors and clients to define the metrics and describe success.<ref name="When It Comes To PR, Pay For Performance, Not Time">{{cite web|last=Konanykhin|first=Alexander|title=When It Comes To PR, Pay For Performance, Not Time|url=http://advertising.about.com/od/publicrelationsresources/a/guestprperform.htm|accessdate=18 March 2012}}</ref>
;Value: The goal of most online business is to generate [[revenue]]. If the system for measurement is transparent and the vendor goals are aligned with client objectives, then the amount of incremental revenue generated by a vendor becomes the final metric for success.<ref name="The Power Of The Pay-For-Performance Model">{{cite web|last=Taulli|first=Tom|title=The Power Of The Pay-For-Performance Model|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomtaulli/2011/02/28/the-power-of-the-pay-for-performance-model/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=10 April 2012}}</ref>
