[[File:GCV Infantry Fighting Vehicle.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Artist's impression of the GCV Infantry Fighting Vehicle]]
The '''Ground Combat Infantry Fighting Vehicle''' was an [[infantry fighting vehicle]] being developed for the [[U.S. Army]]. The program originated as the lead vehicle of the U.S. Army's [[BCT Ground Combat Vehicle Program|Ground Combat Vehicle]] program coordinated by [[TACOM]] and spawned a parallel program coordinated by [[DARPA]]. The purpose of the program was to replace existing [[armored personnel carriers]] and infantry fighting vehicles in U.S. Army service. <!--The TACOM project aims to produce a [[prototype]] by 2015 and begin fielding by 2018 and --> The DARPA project aimed to have the vehicle designed by 2015.<ref name="Crains resubmit">{{cite web|title=Contractors to resubmit bids for revamped military vehicle program|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20100926/SUB01/309269952/contractors-to-resubmit-bids-for-revamped-military-vehicle-program|publisher=Crain Communications Inc. |accessdate=27 September 2010|author=Chad Halcom|date=26 September 2010}}</ref> Derivatives of the vehicle based on a common [[chassis]]—such as tanks and [[ambulance]]s—were expected to be manufactured. It replaced the previous attempt at a next-generation infantry transport, the [[Future Combat Systems Manned Ground Vehicles#Infantry carrier vehicle|XM1206 Infantry Carrier Vehicle]].<ref name=replace>{{cite web|first= |last= |url= http://www.asdnews.com/news/21975/Army_Partially_Terminates_FCS_Manned_Ground_Vehicle.htm |title= Army Partially Terminates FCS Manned Ground Vehicle |work= asdnews.com |publisher= |date= July 21, 2009 |accessdate= January 27, 2010}}</ref> The Ground Combat Vehicle program was cancelled in February 2014.<ref name="defensenews6april14">[http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140406/DEFREG02/304060009/US-Army-Marines-Struggle-Infantry-Vehicle-Replacements US Army, Marines Struggle With Infantry Vehicle Replacements] - Defensenews.com, 6 April 2014</ref>
== Design ==
The Army emphasized affordability, rapid deployment, and low risk technology for the GCV. The Army required that all aspects of the Ground Combat Vehicle be at [[technology readiness level]] 6.<ref name="Greg">{{cite web|title=Army Wants Tough GCV Battle|url=http://www.dodbuzz.com/2010/03/05/army-wants-tough-gcv-competition/|publisher=Military Advantage|accessdate=11 August 2010|author=Greg Grant|date=March 5, 2010}}</ref><ref name="contracting.tacom.army.mil">{{cite web|first=|last=|url=http://contracting.tacom.army.mil/majorsys/gcv/attach/Attch%200001_GCV%20IFV%20Statement%20of%20Work_RFP%20Amendments.pdf|title=Ground Combat Vehicle Infantry Fighting Vehicle Statement of Work|work=[[United States Army]]|publisher=|date=March 15, 2009|accessdate=April 7, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The shortfalls of rapid deployment would be mitigated through an incremental addition of components as technology matures.<ref name=Optimizing /> The Army provided details from the Manned Ground Vehicle effort to utilize on the GCV.<ref name="contracting.tacom.army.mil"/> The GCV was required to have better protection than any vehicle in the military's inventory.<ref name="Industry day 1">{{cite web|title=Industry day #1|url=http://contracting.tacom.army.mil/majorsys/gcv/ID_1_Master_19Oct091.pptx|accessdate=19 September 2010|author=MT Kash|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722183427/http://contracting.tacom.army.mil/majorsys/gcv/ID_1_Master_19Oct091.pptx#|archive-date=2011-07-22|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
General [[Peter W. Chiarelli]] said that the "four main fundamentals" of the vehicle were: The ability to carry 12 soldiers and operate in all forms of combat; have significant protection; and deliver the first production vehicle by 2018.<ref name="$462 million" />
The IFV would be [[Modular design|modular]] and [[BCT Network|networked]] and offer improved survivability, mobility, and power management functions. The GCV family would use technologies pioneered with the IFV lead vehicle effort.<ref>{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://defense-update.com/newscast/0909/news/220909_ground_combat_vehicle.html|title=U.S. Army Defines Ground Combat Vehicles (GCV) Priorities |work= [[Defense Update]] |publisher= |accessdate=March 29, 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Mounted Soldier System cropped.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Mounted Soldier System]] will be standard wear for GCV crew members.]] The [[Mounted Soldier System]] (MSS) was being developed for GCV crew members.<ref name="Industry day 1" /> MSS worked as a [[Force multiplication|force multiplier]] enhancing [[situation awareness]], comfort, and safety.<ref name="MSS">{{cite web|title=Mounted Soldier System (MSS) |url=https://peosoldier.army.mil/FactSheets/PMSWAR/SWAR_MSS_MSS.pdf |accessdate=9 August 2010 |date=May 2010 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Dismounted leaders will utilize the Ground Soldier Systems.<ref name="Industry day 1" />
=== Network ===
The IFV would be operable with the current Battle Command Control and Communications Suite but would gradually use a more revolutionary networked integration system. The system would support integration with unmanned systems, and dismounted soldiers, providing adaptive access points and connectivity.<ref name=GCVspecs>{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://defense-update.com/features/2010/january/gcv_army_details_100110.html |title=U.S. Army Outlines Ground Combat Vehicles Priorities |publisher=Defense update |accessdate= January 26, 2010}}</ref> The new network concept called for [[decentralization]] of decision making.<ref name="Future Operational Concepts">{{cite web|title=The Ground Combat Vehicle In the Conduct of Future Operational Concepts|url=http://www.bctmod.army.mil/GCV_focus/GCV%20CONOPS.pdf|accessdate=17 August 2010|date=August 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101011202739/http://www.bctmod.army.mil/GCV_focus/GCV%20CONOPS.pdf#|archive-date=2010-10-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The Mounted Soldier System was to enhance situational awareness through wireless communications and input from vehicle sensors and external sources such as other vehicles.<ref name=MSS />
=== Electrical power ===
The IFV would provide exportable electrical power, and battery charging capability for soldier systems.<ref name=GCVspecs/>
=== Countermeasures ===
Thermal management and acoustic noise reduction would be utilized to avoid detection. The vehicle would be able to avoid threats by laying [[Smoke screen|obscurants]]. An array of [[Active protection system|hit avoidance systems]] would be leveraged and the Army offered the various [[active protection system]]s developed for the manned ground vehicle program.<ref name="Industry day 1" /> The GCV enabled the detection and neutralization of mines at standoff ranges.<ref name="mine neutalizer">{{cite web|title=Towards a Comprehensive Vehicle Strategy|url=http://www.dtic.mil/ndia/2009combatvehicle/GeneralVane.pdf|date=13 October 2009}}</ref> The vehicle was also to be equipped with an engagement detection system. The Army required the IFV to have the passive blast protection level equal to the [[MRAP (armored vehicle)|MRAP]].<ref name=GCVspecs/> The Army made available the composition of the armor of the manned ground vehicle program. A [[transparent armor]] shield would provide protection for the vehicle commander when exposed through the turret. Personnel would leverage harnesses and restraints to mitigate trauma. In addition, a Vehicle Health Management System would provide vehicle diagnostic monitoring systems for commanders. A fire suppression system and ammunition detonation protection would be utilized for damage control.<ref name="Industry day 1" />
The Mounted Soldier System would protect crew members from ballistic, thermal, and [[Chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear|CBRN]] threats. The Mounted Soldier System incorporated [[fire retardant]] systems such as the Improved Combat Vehicle Crewman Coverall and undergarments, facewear, gloves, and [[tanker boot|footwear]]. Ballistic protection would come from the Combat Vehicle Crewman Helmet, eyewear, a [[Ballistic face mask|maxillofacial shield]], and improvements to body armor.<ref name=MSS /> A secondary squad egress was to be provided for the squad to exit in emergencies.<ref name="Industry day 1" />
== Tactics == The Infantry Fighting Vehicle variant was intended to fill the infantry transport role in [[Brigade Combat Team#Heavy brigade combat team|Heavy Brigade Combat Teams]] replacing the aging [[M113 armored personnel carrier|M113 APC]], [[M2 Bradley]], and [[M1126 Infantry Carrier Vehicle]].<ref name=replace/><ref name=Optimizing /> It was the U.S. Army's intention that the IFV replace the M113 APC in the near term, and the M2 Bradley and M1126 ICV in the midterm.<ref name=Optimizing>{{cite web |url=http://www.bctmod.army.mil/GCV_focus/GCV%20Narrative.pdf |title=The ground combat vehicle strategy: Optimizing for the future |publisher=U.S. Army |accessdate=December 14, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430044607/http://www.bctmod.army.mil/GCV_focus/GCV%20Narrative.pdf |archivedate=April 30, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Matthew |last=Cox |url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4271063&c=AME&s=LAN |title=U.S. Army Details Ground Combat Vehicle Plans |work=[[Defense News]] |publisher=Army Times Publishing Company |date=September 10, 2009 |accessdate=December 13, 2009}}</ref>
In the U.S. Army, as part of the ongoing restructuring, [[Brigade Combat Team#Heavy brigade combat team|Heavy Brigade Combat Team]] Brigades would have an arsenal of 62 IFV's, [[battalion]]s would have 29, and [[platoon]]s would have 4.<ref name="Future Operational Concepts" /><ref name="GCV PROGRAM PLAN" /> Platoons were to be led by platoon leader GCV which would be accompanied by platoon medic, [[Artillery observer|forward observer]], Radio Transmission Operator, and other attachments and would command three other GCVs.<ref name="Future Operational Concepts" />
The Army placed importance on the GCV's ability to carry a full nine-man squad. Numerous Army studies have concluded that a squad, containing two [[fireteam]]s, should be composed of nine to eleven soldiers. These numbers allow the squad to accomplish the [[Fire and Movement|fire and maneuver]] doctrine, and for squad resilience, lethality, and leader span of control. The M2 Bradley cannot carry a complete squad from one vehicle, creating risk when transitioning from mounted to dismounted operations. The Bradley's lower carrying capacity was accepted for greater (than previous vehicles) mounted lethality and cost savings, leading to squads being broken apart for transport. A GCV with a nine-man squad would have allowed the squad leader to control and communicate with the squad while mounted, simplify the transition to dismounted operations in complex terrain, and allow the squad to conduct independent fire and maneuver immediately upon dismount. Replacing the Bradley on a one-for-one basis would have four GCVs per mechanized infantry platoon carrying one full nine-man squad in a single vehicle, with three vehicles carrying squads and one carrying the platoon's organic and attached enablers.<ref>[http://www.rand.org/pubs/research_reports/RR184.html Understanding Why a Ground Combat Vehicle That Carries Nine Dismounts Is Important to the Army] - Rand.org, 11 June 2013</ref>
== Development == The Ground Combat Vehicle was envisioned to be a model of acquisition reform.<ref name="Case for GCV">{{cite web|title=Ground Combat Requires an Adaptable, Versatile Vehicle|url=http://www.bctmod.army.mil/GCV_focus/Case%20for%20%20GCV.pdf|accessdate=17 August 2010|date=August 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101011190145/http://www.bctmod.army.mil/GCV_focus/Case%20for%20%20GCV.pdf#|archive-date=2010-10-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The initial program was canceled a year into development and was soon replaced with a new program better emphasizing affordability.
=== Initial program === [[File:GCV Infantry Fighting Vehicle schedule (January 2010).png|thumb|right|300px|IFV schedule as of January 2010]] [[File:Puma, first series.jpg|right|thumb|The German [[Puma (IFV)|Puma]] is one of the best protected infantry fighting vehicles]]
In the initial plan, the first variant of the vehicle was to be prototyped in 2015 and fielded by 2017.<ref name="GCV PROGRAM PLAN" /> The U.S. military planned on procuring 1,450 IFVs at a total program cost of $40 billion.<ref name="1,450">{{cite web|title=Panel rejects bid to divert funds for Bradley upgrades|url=http://www.govexec.com/dailyfed/0810/080410cdam2.htm|publisher=NATIONAL JOURNAL GROUP, INC.|accessdate=4 August 2010|author=Megan Scully|date=4 August 2010}}</ref> The program was abruptly canceled in August 2010, before any contracts were awarded.<ref name=delay />
;Conception [[File:BCT Ground Combat Vehicle industry day 2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Vice Chief of Staff of the U.S. Army]] General [[Peter W. Chiarelli|Peter Chiarelli]] hosts the second Industry Day meeting]]
An Army presentation in March revealed that [[TARDEC]], [[United States Army Research Laboratory|ARL]], and [[United States Army Training and Doctrine Command|TRADOC]] - ARCIC had partnered to analyze the survivability of the army's "Ground Combat Vehicle".<ref name="First mention">{{cite web|title=Advanced Planning Briefing to Industry|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:f8sj5VSJUt8J:contracting.tacom.army.mil/future_buys/FY09/Bochenek.pdf+%22Ground+Combat+Vehicle%22&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShNA_mYsS0QLPUy6mlU7dIQhZ75P0JumKgbBYNYLZKyyuR3OtO6FnP85UAZkyS4Wg-DlWiM5Q1Ury6YGHaTd_YLa7pdTKUgEmIropLrNIDgUvMukH_oVX5y-_3jk9--p5YHuw4B&sig=AHIEtbQ612_P5ABuC4aXPAfDoQyKJIxHMw|accessdate=26 October 2010|date=19 March 2009}}</ref> Army Chief of Staff Robert Gates announced his intention of halting funding for the XM1206 Infantry Carrier Vehicle of the FCS manned ground vehicle program in April 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title= McHugh nervous about changes|url=http://www.watertowndailytimes.com/article/20090410/NEWS02/304109961|publisher=Watertown Daily Times|accessdate=9 August 2010|author=Marc Heller|date=10 April 2009}}</ref> In late May, Army and Department of Defense representatives outlined plans for the cancellation of Future Combat Systems and the initiation of the Ground Combat Vehicle program in its place.<ref name="28 May 2009">{{cite web|title=US Army outlines how it will 'devolve' FCS|url=http://www.janes.com/news/defence/jdw/jdw090528_1_n.shtml|publisher=IHS Global Limited|accessdate=9 August 2010|author=Daniel Wasserbly|date=28 May 2009}}</ref> On 15 and 16 June, a [[blue-ribbon panel]] convened in Washington D.C. to determine the requirements for the Ground Combat Vehicle.<ref>{{cite web |first=Gina |last=Cavallaro |url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2009/06/army_ground_combat_vehicle_061109w/ |title= Panel to discuss new ground combat vehicle |work=[[Army Times]] |publisher=[[Army Times Publishing Company]] |date=June 11, 2009 |accessdate=December 14, 2009}}</ref> It was concluded at this meeting that an Infantry Fighting Vehicle was to be the first vehicle variant fielded.<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. Army Details Ground Combat Vehicle Plans|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4271063|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=20 August 2010|author=Matthew Cox|date=10 June 2009}}</ref> Defense contractors were not allowed to attend but at least six in attendance were employed by defense companies that eventually bid on the GCV contract.<ref>{{cite web|title= Home / News / Nation The Boston Globe From the Pentagon to the private sector|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2010/12/26/defense_firms_lure_retired_generals/?page=3|publisher=NY Times Co.|accessdate=26 December 2010|author=Bryan Bender|date=26 December 2010}}</ref> On 23 June, Future Combat Systems was formally dissolved and many programs including the Manned Ground Vehicle program were canceled with it.<ref>[http://www.defenselink.mil/releases/release.aspx?releaseid=12763 "Future Combat System (FCS) Program Transitions to Army Brigade Combat Team Modernization"], US DoD, 23 June 2009.</ref> On 19 October, contractors turned up for a U.S. Army organized [[industry day]] event in [[Dearborn, Michigan]] to learn about the requirements.<ref>{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.bctmod.army.mil/news/pdf/GCV_Industry_Day.pdf |title=U.S. Army Announces Ground Combat Vehicle Industry Day |work=US Army |publisher=US Army |date=October 2009 |accessdate=October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430044617/http://www.bctmod.army.mil/news/pdf/GCV_Industry_Day.pdf |archivedate=2011-04-30 |df= }}</ref> In late October [https://www.fcs.army.mil/Program_Executive_Office_Integration.html PEO Integration]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} was established to oversee subsystems of BCT Modernization including the GCV.<ref>{{cite web|title=Army Establishes Program Executive Office Integration to Support Modernization|url=http://www.army.mil/-news/2009/10/02/28280-army-establishes-program-executive-office-integration-to-support-modernization/|accessdate=11 August 2010|author=Jimmie Cummings|date=2 October 2009}}</ref> On 24 November, a second industry day was held in [[Warren, Michigan]].<ref>{{cite web |first= Margaret |last= Nelson |url=http://www.army.mil/-news/2009/11/25/31026-us-army-meets-with-industry-representatives-to-conceive-a-ground-combat-vehicle |title=U.S. Army meets with industry representatives to conceive a ground combat vehicle |work=US Army |publisher=US Army |date= November 25, 2009 |accessdate= November 2009}}</ref>
After much delay, reviews necessary for continuation were held throughout February, in Washington D.C.<ref>{{cite web |first= Kate |last= Brannen |url= http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4494373&c=AME&s=LAN|title= DoD Postpones Ground Combat Vehicle Review |work= [[Defense News]] |publisher= |date=February 11, 2010 |accessdate=February 11, 2010}}</ref> The GCV review was officially passed on 25 February and a request for proposal (RfP) was issued the same day.<ref name=Kate>{{cite web |first=Kate |last=Brannen |url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2010/02/defense_army_gcv_rfp_022510w/|title= Army to issue Ground Combat Vehicle RfP today |work= [[Defense News]] |publisher= |date=February 25, 2010 |accessdate=February 25, 2010}}</ref> It was revealed in the RfP that the GCV would be a [[cost-plus contract]].<ref name="Brannen RfP">{{cite web|title=Army launches Ground Combat Vehicle contest|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2010/02/army_dn022610_GCV_web/|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=1 October 2010|author=Kate Brannen|date=26 February 2010}}</ref> Companies had 60 days to respond, but this offer was extended an additional 25 days.<ref name=Kate/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shephard.co.uk/news/landwarfareintl-com/us-army-delays-gcv-deadline/6155/|title=US Army delays GCV deadline|last=White|first=Andrew|date=19 April 2010|work=Shephard|publisher=Shephard Group Limited|accessdate=19 April 2010}}</ref> In May, a "red team" was formed to curtail the GCVs 7-year development schedule.<ref>{{cite web|title=Experts Study U.S. Army's GCV Plans, Schedule|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4619649|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=11 November 2010|author=Kate Brannen|date=10 May 2010}}</ref> By the 21 May deadline, four proposals were submitted.<ref name="ADVS" /> On 1 July, management of the GCV was transferred from PEO Integration to [http://www.peogcs.army.mil/index.html PEO Ground Combat Systems] with Andrew DiMarco as [[project manager]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2010/07/mil-100727-arnews05.htm|title=The future of ground combat vehicles resides with PEO Ground Combat Systems|publisher=GlobalSecurity.org|accessdate=11 August 2010|author=Lori Grein|date=July 27, 2010}}</ref>
For [[2011 United States federal budget|fiscal year 2011]], the U.S. Army intended to spend $934 million of the $2.5 billion allocated for BCT Modernization to develop the GCV.<ref>{{cite web |first= Matthew|last= Cox|url= http://www.armytimes.com/news/2010/02/army_procurement_020110w/ |title= No more Humvees in 2011 procurement plan |work= [[Army Times]] |publisher= Army Times Publishing Company|date= February 1, 2010 |accessdate= February 2, 2010}}</ref> Reportedly, $100 million was removed from the yet to be approved budget but the budget continued to reported as $934 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=House panel risks veto by supporting funds for second F-35 fighter engine|url=http://thehill.com/news-by-subject/defense-homeland-security/111145-house-panel-risks-veto-by-supporting-second-f-35-engine|publisher=Capitol Hill Publishing Corp.|accessdate=28 July 2010|author=Roxana Tiron|date=27 July 2010}}</ref>
On 25 August the Army retracted its request for proposals after the red team assembled in May recommended that the Army either upgrade the existing ground vehicle fleet or rewrite the requirements.<ref name="delay">{{cite web|title=Army delays Ground Combat Vehicle|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2010/08/DN_army-army-delays-gcv-082510/|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=26 August 2010|author=John T. Bennett|author2=Kate Brannen|date=26 August 2010}}</ref>
;Projections The Technology Development Phase (or Milestone A) was to begin with the award of up to three vehicle contracts awarded in late Fiscal Year 2010 under the Technology Development Phase Contract. A Preliminary Design Review would follow in mid FY 2012.<ref name="GCV PROGRAM PLAN">{{cite web|title=GCV PROGRAM PLAN|url=http://contracting.tacom.army.mil/majorsys/gcv/attach/Attch%200008_GCV%20Program%20Schedule.pdf|accessdate=5 August 2010|date=29 January 2010}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The U.S. military planned to spend $7.6 billion during Milestone A.<ref name="Lucrative contracts">{{cite web|title=Contractors vie for lucrative vehicle work|url=http://thehill.com/business-a-lobbying/112959-top-contractors-vie-for-lucrative-vehicle-work|publisher=Capitol Hill Publishing Corp.|accessdate=6 August 2010|author=Roxana Tiron|date=6 August 2010}}</ref>
The Engineering and Manufacturing Development Phase (or Milestone B) was to begin with two prototype development contracts awarded in the beginning of Fiscal Year 2013 under the Engineering & Manufacturing Development Contract. Shortly thereafter, an Interim Critical Design Review would follow in Mid-FY 2013. After a nearly two-year manufacturing period the first prototypes would be manufactured Mid-FY 2015 after which a Critical Design Review and a Production Readiness Review would occur in FY 2015 and FY 2016 respectively.<ref name="GCV PROGRAM PLAN" />
The Low Rate Initial Production Phase (or Milestone C) was to begin with a low-rate production contract awarded in mid Fiscal Year 2016 under the Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) contract. Less than two years after the contract award LRIP would begin. After more testing a [[battalion]]-sized team would be attained in FY 2018 followed by a [[brigade]]-sized arsenal in FY 2019.<ref name="GCV PROGRAM PLAN" />
If a Full-Rate Production Decision was attained, full-rate production would begin. The U.S. military planned on procuring 1,450 IFVs at a total program cost of $40 billion.<ref name="GCV PROGRAM PLAN" /><ref name=1,450/>
;Competitors There were four known competing contractors for the Ground Combat Vehicle contract.
[[File:BAE Northrop GCV.jpg|thumb|right|Concept image of BAE contender]] *[[BAE Systems]], [[Northrop Grumman]], [[QinetiQ]] and [[Saft Groupe S.A.|Saft Group]] were working jointly on development.<ref>{{cite web |first= |last= |url= http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9E62TB00.htm|title= BAE, Northrop to develop new ground combat vehicle|work= |publisher= The Associated Press|date= March 1, 2010|accessdate= March 2010}}</ref> The program was managed by Mark Signorelli.<ref name="BAE 1">{{cite web|title=BAE Offers Hybrid-Electric Combat Vehicle|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/defense/2010/06/bae-offers-hybridelectric.php|publisher=National Journal Group Inc|accessdate=18 June 2010|author=Sydney J. Freedberg Jr.}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="BAE Businessweek ">{{cite web|title=BAE, Northrop expand team to bid on Army contract|url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9H6UDBO2.htm|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=27 July 2010|date=26 July 2010}}</ref> The team believed it could field the vehicle up to two years sooner than projected.<ref name=ausa /> Development cost were "tens of millions of dollars".<ref name="GCV reform 2">{{cite web|title=Army sees new rules for combat vehicles soon|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE69L55W20101022|publisher=Thomson Reuters|accessdate=23 October 2010|author=Andrea Shalal-Esa|date=22 October 2010}}</ref>
:*'''Work breakdown'''<ref name="BAE Businessweek" /> ::*BAE would provide general vehicle design, program management, integration of the vehicle components. ::*Northrop Grumman would provide technology pertaining to command, control, communications, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance. ::*QinetiQ would provide the electric drive propulsion system. ::*Saft would provide the energy storage system.
:*'''Features''' ::*Tracked with an [http://www.baesystems.com/cs/groups/public/documents/document/mdaw/mtew/~edisp/baes_102040.pdf E-X-Drive] hybrid-electric engine.<ref name="BAE Businessweek" /> ::*Baseline weight of 53 tons with a weight tolerance of 75 tons for modular armor.<ref name="BAE GCV">{{cite web|title=Firm wants Army to use hybrid technology on GCV|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2010/07/army_gcv_hybrid_electric_072610w/|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=27 July 2010|author=Kate Brannen|date=26 July 2010}}</ref> ::*Manned turret.<ref name="BAE GCV" /> ::*Leveraged a [[V-hull]] and Hard-Kill and Soft-Kill [[active protection system]]s.<ref name="BAE shape">{{cite web|title=BAE-Northrop GCV Hybrid Drive A Gamble|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/asd/2010/07/28/06.xml&headline=BAE-Northrop%20GCV%20Hybrid%20Drive%20A%20Gamble|publisher= The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc|accessdate=28 July 2010|author=Michael Fabey|date=28 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="BAE’s GCV">{{cite web|title=BAE’s GCV Weighs 53 Tons, Hybrid|publisher=Military Advantage|author=Colin Clark|date=28 July 2010}}</ref> ::*Wider and taller than a Bradley. All or most of the storage was internal accounting for the extra size.<ref name="BAE shape" />
*[[General Dynamics Land Systems]], [[Lockheed Martin]], [[Detroit Diesel]] and [[Raytheon]] were working jointly on development.<ref name="General Dynamics">{{cite web|title=General Dynamics Team Submits Army Ground Combat Vehicle Proposal|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/general-dynamics-team-submits-army-ground-combat-vehicle-proposal-94578069.html|publisher=PR Newswire Association LLC.|accessdate=21 May 2010}}</ref>
:*'''Work breakdown'''<ref name="General Dynamics" /> ::*General Dynamics Land Systems led the team as systems integrator and was responsible for soldier interfaces and chassis. ::*Lockheed Martin would develop the turret and weaponry. ::*Detroit Diesel would develop the propulsion system. ::*Raytheon would develop the [[active protection system]]s, sensors.
:*'''Features''' ::*Used conventional diesel.<ref name="BAE 1" /> ::*Used active protection systems.<ref name="General Dynamics" /> ::*Designers “paid a lot attention” to human accommodations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Waiting for the Ground Combat Vehicle|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&newspaperUserId=27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3A945ac87c-0f86-4806-b5cf-8b45a959ad18&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest|accessdate=3 November 2010|author=Paul Mcleary|date=28 October 2010}}</ref>
*[[Science Applications International Corporation|SAIC]] led a consortium called Team Full Spectrum which included [[Boeing]], [[Krauss-Maffei]] and [[Rheinmetall]].<ref name="ausa">{{cite web|title=Ground Combat Vehicle|url=http://www.ausa.org/publications/armymagazine/archive/2010/8/Documents/SA_0810.pdf|publisher=AUSA|accessdate=21 August 2010|author=Scott R. Gourley|date=August 2010}}</ref> The SAIC consortium is using a derivative of the [[Puma (IFV)|Puma]].<ref name="PUMA">{{cite web|last=White|first=Andrew|title=GCV shortlist revealed|url=http://www.shephard.co.uk/news/landwarfareint/gcv-shortlist-revealed/6378/|publisher=Shephard Group Limited.|accessdate=21 May 2010}}</ref>
:*'''Work breakdown'''<ref name="PUMA"/> ::*SAIC would lead the team as project manager. ::*Boeing would supply the weaponry. ::*Both Krauss-Maffei and Rheinmetall's roles were unknown.
:*'''Features''' ::*Larger, reconfigured Puma chassis.<ref name="PUMA"/> ::*Used conventional diesel and a six-road-wheel configuration.<ref name="BAE 1" /> *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090305065136/http://www.advs.com/Site/Advanced%20Defense%20Vehicle%20Systems.html Advanced Defense Vehicle Systems] (ADVS) submitted its wheeled proposal which was rejected for being non-compliant. A protest was filed by the company and assessed and ruled upon by September 27.<ref name="ADVS">{{cite web|title=U.S. Army GCV Protest Not Expected to Cause Delay|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4679299&c=AME&s=LAN|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=23 June 2010|author=Kate Brannen}}</ref> After cancellation of the RfP, ADVS withdrew its protest.<ref name="Crains resubmit" />
:*'''Work breakdown'''<ref name="ADVS" /> ::*ADVS led the team. ::*Had undisclosed subcontractors.
:*'''Features''' ::*Wheeled.<ref>{{cite web|title=Michigan Company Protests Rejection Of Its Wheeled GCV Bid|url=https://defensenewsstand.com/Inside-the-Army/Inside-the-Army-06/28/2010/menu-id-288.html|publisher=Inside Washington Publishers|accessdate=6 August 2010|date=June 28, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709010646/https://defensenewsstand.com/Inside-the-Army/Inside-the-Army-06/28/2010/menu-id-288.html#|archive-date=2011-07-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
=== Revised program === In September, [[Alion Science and Technology]] was awarded a $23,828,000 contract modification for the development of systems supporting GCV development. This contract was tendered by the U.S. Air Force and $2,180,000 in funds was obligated at the time of the award.<ref name="1st contract">{{cite web|title=Contracts|url=http://www.defense.gov/contracts/contract.aspx?contractid=4377|accessdate=30 September 2010|date=29 September 2010}}</ref> An industry day was held 1 October in Dearborn, Michigan.<ref name="Tiered">{{cite web|title=U.S. Army to Set Out Tiered Requirements for GCV|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4826208&c=LAN&s=TOP|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=26 October 2010|author=Kate Brannen|date=5 October 2010}}</ref> The Army reduced its requested FY 2011 budget to $462 million.<ref name="$462 million">{{cite web|title=Fewer FCS Technologies for GCV Round Two|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4787151&c=LAN&s=TOP|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=23 September 2010|author=Kate Brannen|date=22 September 2010}}</ref> Advanced Defense Vehicle Systems, General Dynamics Land Systems, and BAE Systems announced their intention of re-competing soon after the cancellation.<ref name="Crains resubmit" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Military vehicle maker drops protest, will try again for government contracts|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20100827/FREE/100829898|publisher=Crain Communications Inc.|accessdate=30 August 2010|author=Chad Halcom|date=27 August 2010}}</ref> A revised RfP was to be issued around 27 October 2010.<ref name="Ground Combat Vehicle Technology Development Phase Solicitation 2">{{cite web|title=10--Ground Combat Vehicle Technology Development Phase Solicitation|url=https://www.fbo.gov/index?s=opportunity&mode=form&tab=core&id=3ca68abe44eae4d617512b7057977a18&_cview=0|accessdate=16 October 2010|date=8 October 2010}}</ref> Military officials met on 20 October to discuss delaying the RfP to allow leaders time to deliberate about requirements. The panel recommended releasing the RfP without delay but George Casey said he would need time to commit to a decision. Senior leaders at the meeting felt that the 27 October target could be met.<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. Army Aiming to Release GCV Request|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4969898|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=13 November 2010|author=Kate Brannen|date=25 October 2010}}</ref> The [[National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform]] suggested deferring development of the GCV until after 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=$200 BILLION IN ILLUSTRATIVE SAVINGS|url=http://www.fiscalcommission.gov/sites/fiscalcommission.gov/files/documents/Illustrative_List_11.10.2010.pdf|accessdate=11 November 2010|date=10 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101119153741/http://www.fiscalcommission.gov/sites/fiscalcommission.gov/files/documents/Illustrative_List_11.10.2010.pdf|archivedate=19 November 2010|df=}}</ref>
{{Wikinewspar|U.S. Army revives next-generation Ground Combat Vehicle program}} The revised RfP was issued on 30 November. ADVS announced its decision to not submit a proposal. ADVS decision not to compete was stated to be that the vehicle's slow procurement timeline was not suited to "ADVS’ rapid development and fielding capabilities".<ref>{{cite web|title=4th GCV team withdraws from competition|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2011/08/defense-gcv-gets-go-ahead-081811/|publisher=Gannett Government Media Corporation|accessdate=19 January 2011|author=Kate Brannen|date=18 January 2011}}</ref>
Up to three [[cost-plus contract]]s were to be awarded nine months after the RfP was released.<ref name=delay /><ref name="Ground Combat Vehicle Technology Development Phase Solicitation 2" /> An acquisition decision memorandum on 17 August allowed the program to award technology development contracts. It also initiated two reviews of alternatives including a revised analysis of alternatives and an analysis of non-developmental vehicles.<ref>{{cite web|title=GCV moves ahead, but more studies ordered|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2011/08/defense-gcv-gets-go-ahead-081811/|publisher=Gannett Government Media Corporation|accessdate=11 September 2011|author=Kate Brannen|date=18 August 2011}}</ref> The 18 August, the Army awarded technology development contracts to only BAE and GDLS. BAE was awarded $450 million while GDLS was awarded $440 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=BAE, GD awarded Ground Combat Vehicle contracts|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2011/08/defense-army-gcv-contract-winners-announced-081811/|publisher=Gannett Government Media Corporation|accessdate=11 September 2011|author=Kate Brannen|date=18 August 2011}}</ref> SAIC followed up with a bid protest on 26 August further delaying GCV development.<ref>{{cite web|title=SAIC-Led Team Protests U.S. Army Combat Vehicle Contracts|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-08-26/saic-boeing-team-said-to-protest-army-combat-vehicle-contracts.html|publisher=Bloomberg L.P|accessdate=11 September 2011|author=Roxana Tiron and Brendan McGarry|date=26 August 2011}}</ref> It believed the evaluations process was flawed and the evaluation took factors into consideration that were not stated in the request for proposal.<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. Ground Combat Vehicle Work Put On Hold|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/asd/2011/08/30/07.xml&headline=U.S.%20Ground%20Combat%20Vehicle%20Work%20Put%20On%20Hold|publisher=Bloomberg L.P|accessdate=11 September 2011|author=Paul McLeary |date=29 August 2011}}</ref>
;Projections $884 million was requested by the U.S. Army to fund the GCV in FY 2012.<ref name="Kate FY 2012">{{cite web|title=Army seeks 30 percent less for overseas ops|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2011/02/defense-army-overseas-ops-budget-021411/|publisher=Gannett Government Media Corporation|accessdate=15 February 2011|author=Kate Brannen|date=15 February 2011}}</ref> The technology development phase was to be a 24 months long, 3 months shorter than the previous plan.<ref name="Revised. Kate Brannen">{{cite web|title=U.S. Army To Host GCV Industry Day Oct. 1|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4787079&c=LAN&s=TOP|publisher=Army Times Publishing Company|accessdate=22 September 2010|author=Kate Brannen|date=22 September 2010}}</ref> The Engineering and Manufacturing Development phase was to be 48 months long.<ref name="revised program Industry day">{{cite web|title=GCV Industry Day|url=http://contracting.tacom.army.mil/majorsys/gcv/GCV%20Industry%20Day%20Brief%20Oct%2010%20Charts.pdf|accessdate=13 November 2010|date=1 October 2010}}</ref> The Army planned on acquiring 1,874 GCVs to replace Bradleys in 16 active and 8 National Guard [[Brigade Combat Team#Armored Brigade Combat Team|Heavy Brigade Combat Teams]].<ref name="BAE">[http://www.armytimes.com/article/20120324/NEWS/203240316/Heavyweight-contender-BAE-offers-70-ton-GCV BAE offers 70-ton GCV] - Armytimes.com, March 27, 2012</ref>
;Milestone A [[File:Namer in US.jpg|thumb|[[Namer APC]] during Non-Developmental Vehicle assessment.]] [[File:CV9035 assessment (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|A [[Combat Vehicle 90|CV-9035]] demonstrator vehicle for the Non-Developmental Vehicle assessment.]] Testing of commercially available combat vehicles began in May 2012 at [[Fort Bliss]] and [[White Sands Missile Range]] to prepare the Army for Milestone B. The Non-Developmental Vehicle analysis assessed five vehicles, the [[M2A3 Bradley]], [[Namer]], [[Combat Vehicle 90|CV-9035]], a double v-hulled [[M1126 Infantry Carrier Vehicle]] and a turretless Bradley. The tests, completed on May 25, were carried out to determine what vehicle variants and configurations fulfill the Army's needs.<ref name="NDV Assessments">{{cite news |title=Army assesses current vehicles as part of Ground Combat Vehicle development process |author=Ashley Piper |url=http://www.army.mil/article/80185/The_Desert_Heats_Up_as_GCV_Kicks_Off_Non_Developmental_Vehicle__NDV__Assessments/ |newspaper=Army News|date=21 May 2012 |accessdate=8 June 2012}}</ref> The Army found that although the vehicles assessed met some GCV requirements, no currently fielded vehicle met enough without needing significant redesign.<ref name="response">[http://www.dodbuzz.com/2013/04/04/army-industry-slam-cbos-scathing-gcv-report/ Army, industry slam CBO’s scathing GCV report] - DoDBuzz.com, April 4, 2013</ref>
;Competitors There were three known competing contractors for the Ground Combat Vehicle contract.
*[[BAE Systems]], [[Northrop Grumman]], [[QinetiQ]] North America, [[Saft Groupe S.A.|Saft Group]], and [[iRobot]] were working jointly on development *[[General Dynamics Land Systems]] led a team that included [[Lockheed Martin]], and [[Raytheon]] *[[Science Applications International Corporation|SAIC]] led a team that include [[Boeing]], [[Krauss-Maffei Wegmann]], and [[Rheinmetall Defence]] (not awarded EMD contract)
;Milestone C A Milestone C decision could have been made in 2019.<ref name="weight">{{cite web|last=Cox|first=Matt|title=Army: GCV Needs to Be Big and Tracked|url=http://defensetech.org/2013/02/21/army-gcv-needs-to-be-big-and-tracked/|publisher=DefenseTech|accessdate=February 26, 2013|date=February 21, 2013}}</ref>
====Weight issues==== In November 2012, estimates of the GCV's weight, depending on armor packages, put the General Dynamics entry vehicle at 64–70 tons, and the BAE Systems entry vehicle at 70–84 tons. This made the planned infantry fighting vehicle designs heavier than the [[M1 Abrams]] tank. The reason was the vehicle had to have enough armor to protect a squad of nine troops from all battlefield threats (from [[rocket-propelled grenade]]s to [[Improvised explosive device| IED]]s) as good as or better than other vehicles can protect against specific threats individually. This worked against the vehicle; as weight increases, cost goes up and maneuverability goes down. The contractors worked to bring the weight down.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://defense.aol.com/2012/11/08/bradley-offspring-gcv-may-top-84-tons-hheavier-than-m1-tank/ | title = Bradley Offspring, GCV, May Top 84 Tons, Heavier Than M1 Tank | newspaper = Defense | publisher = AOL | date = November 8, 2012 | access-date = 2012-11-13 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121112072248/http://defense.aol.com/2012/11/08/bradley-offspring-gcv-may-top-84-tons-hheavier-than-m1-tank# | archive-date = 2012-11-12 | dead-url = yes | df = }}.</ref> The Army maintained that heavy armor was needed to protect the squad from acceleration forces that come with an underside blast, and that thicker underbelly plates and [[V-hull| V-shaped hulls]] do not give enough protection. More armor would come from the vehicle being larger for more internal space for the soldiers, and to allow for features such as floating floors for blast deflection and extra headroom. The Army also said heavy weight would not affect deployability because the Bradley it was planned replace already requires [[Airlift#Strategic airlift| strategic airlift]] [[Military transport aircraft|transport aircraft]].<ref name = "weight "/>
Both contractors claimed their designs were below the 70–84 tons expectation of what the GCV will weigh. BAE's vehicle weighed 60–70 tons, based on modular armor package, and a 20 percent margin for weight increase the Army had planned for future upgrades would bring it up to 84 tons. General Dynamic's vehicle with a diesel engine weighed 62 tons in its most heavily armored configuration, which increased to 76 tons with the 20 percent future upgrade margin. Removing protection for easier air transportation would have reduced it to 56 tons. The Army's consideration to slow down the GCV development program gave time to the companies to refine their designs and reduce weight. One way would have been to reduce squad size. A nine-man squad has been identified as best for being able to fight with the possibility of taking casualties with single-vehicle transportability. With a three-man crew, the GCV had to carry 12 men. A greater number of lighter IFVs that carry fewer soldiers would have similar carrying capacity and combined costs and weight to planned GCV numbers. Another way would be an advance in armor designs. Lighter and stronger armor materials had not made radical progressions in recent history, and domestic active protection intercept systems were not yet mature. Foreign systems like the Israeli [[Trophy (countermeasure) | Trophy]] had seen combat but cannot yet intercept tank shells. The GCV program originally included an APS, but was then delayed as a feature for later upgrades. The last effort to replace the Bradley was with [[Future Combat Systems]], which developed a vehicle that relied on sensors to avoid danger and an APS in place of heavy armor. It was too ambitious for the time and the vehicle's weight had grown from 19 tons to 30 tons by the time it was cancelled.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://breakingdefense.com/2013/11/bae-general-dynamics-we-can-get-weight-down-on-army-gcv/ | title = BAE, GD: We Can Cut Weight From Army’s GCV | newspaper = Breaking defense | date = 27 November 2013}}.</ref>
==Vehicles==
===BAE Systems=== The [[BAE Systems]] Ground Combat Vehicle design had a steel-core hull and an integrated electronic network capability with embedded intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance equipment. Its turret was unmanned. The centerpiece of the vehicle was its simplified drive train. It was propelled by a Hybrid Electric Drive (HED), which was developed by [[Northrop Grumman]], that produced 1,100 kW of electricity. Advantages to it are fewer components and lower volume and weight compared to current power plants. The transmission was 40 percent smaller and the drive train had half the moving parts. The hybrid drive train cost 5 percent more than a mechanical system, but had a 20 percent reduction in life-cycle cost. The electric drive allows for smoother low-speed operation and less noise. The vehicle burned 20 percent less fuel while running, with 4.61 gallons (17.45 liters) per hour used while stationary. It had a top speed of 43 mph (70 km/h), could go from 0 to 20 mph (32.18 km/hr) in 7.8 seconds, and had a range of {{convert|186|mi|km|abbr=on}} with a 255-gallon fuel capacity. Disadvantages to the BAE design included a weight of 70 tons and fuel efficiency of only 0.73 mpg. It was argued that big, heavy vehicles are not practical in urban combat and that the infrastructure of urban and third-world countries should limit the vehicle's weight to 45 tons. Others said that urban warfare tactics have become so lethal that only vehicles of this size can survive.<ref name="BAE"/><ref>[http://www.gizmag.com/bae-gcv-hybrid-tank/25113/ BAE Systems releases details of hybrid tank] - Gizmag.com, November 22, 2012</ref> BAE integrated the [[Artis, LLC|Artis]] [[Iron Curtain active protection system]] to defeat incoming rockets and missiles before they can hit the vehicle. The Army conducted tests on the system in April 2013, and the it successfully passed all tests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://defense-update.com/20130429_iron-curtain-tested.html|title=Iron Curtain Successful in Firing Tests|publisher=Defense Update |date=April 29, 2013|accessdate=2013-05-08}}</ref> A prototype system for the vehicle to drive in low visibility conditions was also tested. A Humvee with blacked-out windows drove through a smoke-filled mock town with the system safely, even though visibility was completely obscured.<ref>[http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/blog/Lists/Posts/Post.aspx?ID=1245 Undeterred By Possible Delays, BAE Continues Ground Combat Vehicle Development] - Nationaldefensemagazine.org, 28 August 2013</ref> In August 2013, the BAE GCV's hybrid electric drive completed 2,000 miles of testing on a fully integrated “Hotbuck” mobility platform. The Hotbuck is a stationary test stand that simulates real-life environments and terrain and puts actual miles on the HED system. Under BAE's own timeline, the testing was completed four months ahead of schedule. Developing and testing actual hardware was not a program requirement for the Technology Development (TD) phase, but BAE Systems chose to demonstrate the fuel efficiency and performance of a hybrid system.<ref>[http://www.armyrecognition.com/august_2013_defense_industry_military_army_news_uk/bae_systems_ground_combat_vehicle_hybrid_electric_drive_successfully_completed_2000_miles_testing.html BAE Systems Ground Combat Vehicle Hybrid Electric Drive successfully completed 2000 miles testing] - Armyrecognition.com, 27 August 2013</ref>
Although dramatic funding cuts for the GCV program in January 2014 put the very completion of the acquisition effort in jeopardy, funding remained for research on a hybrid-electric propulsion system. The BAE GCV's hybrid-electric engine is more fuel efficient, has fewer moving parts, and has faster acceleration than ordinary engines. While powering a vehicle concept that reached 70 tons proved impractical, its benefits of providing power for onboard electronics, silent overwatch, and short, stealthy movements are still promising. BAE has pledged to support future Army developmental efforts with technologies from their GCV entry.<ref>[http://www.dodbuzz.com/2014/01/22/hopes-dim-for-baes-green-combat-vehicle/ Hopes Dim for BAE’s ‘Green’ Combat Vehicle] - DoDBuzz.com, 22 January 2014</ref> On 18 July 2014, BAE Systems was awarded a $7.9 million study contract for technical, cost, and risk assessments to utilize the GCV TD phase integrated hybrid-electric propulsion and mobility subsystems Automotive Test Rig (ATR) and the hybrid-electric integrated propulsion subsystem (Hotbuck) for the Future Fighting Vehicle (FFV) effort.<ref>[http://www.defensemedianetwork.com/stories/army-attempts-to-salvage-gcv-technology-advances/ Army Attempts to Salvage GCV Technology Advances] - Defensemedianetwork.com, 25 July 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.militaryaerospace.com/articles/2014/08/gcv-ffv-technologies.html Army asks BAE Systems and General Dynamics to recycle GCV vetronics for Future Fighting Vehicle] - Militaryaerospace.com, 18 August 2014</ref>
===General Dynamics GCV=== On 31 October 2013, General Dynamics successfully completed a preliminary design review of their GCV IFV design. Subsystem and component design reviews were held from August to October of that year and led to the four-day PDR. General Dynamics demonstrated their vehicle met Tier 1 affordability, reliability, and other requirements. The success of the PDR meant that the General Dynamics GCV IFV could be expected to be operationally effective and suitable.<ref>[https://archive.is/20131109162004/http://www.armyrecognition.com/november_2013_defense_industry_military_news_uk/general_dynamics_completed_preliminary_design_revuiew_of_gcv_ground_combat_vehicle_design_0911132.html General Dynamics completed Preliminary Design Review of Ground Combat Vehicle design] - Armyrecognition.com, 9 November 2013</ref>

{{short description|Remotely observe movement or migratory patterns in a wild animal using the Global Positioning System}} {{redirect|Wildlife tracking|other methods of wildlife tracking|animal migration tracking|and|History of wildlife tracking technology}} '''GPS wildlife tracking''' is a process whereby [[biologists]], scientific researchers or conservation agencies can remotely observe relatively fine-scale movement or [[wikt:migration|migratory]] patterns in a free-ranging wild animal using the [[Global Positioning System]] and optional environmental sensors or automated data-retrieval technologies such as [[Argos system|Argos]] satellite uplink, [[Circuit Switched Data|mobile data telephony]] or [[GPRS]] and a range of analytical software tools.<ref>Schofield, Gail et al., "Novel GPS tracking of sea turtles as a tool for conservation management", ''Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology'' 347 (2007) 58–68</ref>
A GPS-enabled device will normally record and store location data at a pre-determined interval or on [[interrupt]] by an environmental sensor. These data may be stored pending recovery of the device or relayed to a central data store or internet-connected computer using an embedded [[cellular network|cellular]] ([[GPRS]]), [[radio]], or [[satellite]] modem. The animal's location can then be plotted against a map or chart in near real-time or, when analysing the track later, using a [[GIS]] package or custom software.
While GPS tracking devices may also be attached to [[domestic animals]] such as [[pets]], [[purebred|pedigree]] [[livestock]] and [[working dogs]], and similar systems are used in [[fleet management]] of vehicles, wildlife tracking can place additional constraints on size and weight and may not allow for post-deployment recharging or replacement of [[Battery (electricity)|batteries]] or correction of attachment.
As well as allowing in-depth study of animal behaviour and migration, the [[high-resolution]] tracks available from a GPS-enabled system can potentially allow for tighter control of animal-borne [[Infectious disease|communicable diseases]] such as the [[H5N1]] strain of [[avian influenza]].<ref>[http://www.usgs.gov/newsroom/article.asp?ID=1547 USGS Release: Satellites Help Scientists Track Migratory Birds: GPS the Latest Tool in Fight Against Avian Influenza (9/6/2006 9:38:16 AM)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Attachment== ===Collar attachment=== [[Image:Jaguar (Panthera onca palustris) male Rio Negro 2.JPG|thumb|A [[jaguar]] wearing a tracking collar]] Collar attachment is the primary attachment technique where the subject has a suitable body type and behaviour. [[Tracking collar]]s would normally be used on the animal's neck (assuming the head has a larger circumference than the neck)<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/6188482.stm BBC NEWS | Technology | Snow leopard fitted with GPS tag<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> but also on a limb, perhaps around an ankle. Suitable animals for neck attachment would include primates, large cats, some bears etc. Limb attachment would work well in animals such as [[kiwi]], where the foot is much larger than the ankle.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}}
===Harness attachment=== Harness attachments may used in situations where collar attachment is not suitable, such as animals whose neck diameter may exceed that of the head. Examples of this type of animal may include pigs, [[Tasmanian devils]], etc.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} Large, long-necked, birds such as the [[greylag goose]] may also need to be fitted with a harness to prevent removal of the tag by the subject.<ref>[http://www.csl.gov.uk/aboutCsl/scienceGroupsAndTeams/ebg/gooseProject/tagging.cfm CSL - Goose Project<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070702233724/http://www.csl.gov.uk/aboutCsl/scienceGroupsAndTeams/ebg/gooseProject/tagging.cfm |date=2007-07-02 }}</ref>
===Direct attachment=== Direct attachment is used on animals where a collar cannot be used, such as birds, reptiles and [[marine mammals]].
In the case of birds, the GPS unit must be very lightweight to avoid interfering with the bird's ability to fly or swim. The device is usually attached by gluing or, for short deployments, taping<ref>P. G. Ryan, S. L. Petersen, G. Peters and D. Grémillet, "GPS tracking a marine predator: the effects of precision, resolution and sampling rate on foraging tracks of African Penguins" in Marine Biology, International Journal on Life in Oceans and Coastal Waters, Volume 145, Number 2, August 2004, pp. 215-223 </ref> to the bird. The unit will then naturally fall off when the bird next moults.
In the case of reptiles such as [[crocodile]]s and [[turtle]]s, gluing the unit onto the animal's skin or [[carapace]] using [[epoxy]] (or similar material) is the most common method and minimises discomfort.<ref>Godley, B.J., et al., "Post-nesting movements and submergence patterns of loggerhead marine turtles in the Mediterranean assessed by satellite tracking", ''Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology'' 287 (2003) p.121</ref>
In deployments on marine mammals such as [[Earless seal|phocids]] or [[Eared seal|otariids]], the device would be glued to the fur and fall off during the annual [[moult]]. Units used with turtles or marine animals have to resist the corrosive effects of sea water and be waterproof to pressures of up to 200bar.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}}
===Other attachment methods=== Other applications include [[rhinoceros]] tracking, for which a hole may be drilled in the animal's horn and a device implanted.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} Compared to other methods, implanted transmitters may suffer from a reduced range as the large mass of the animal's body can absorb some transmitted power.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}}
There are also GPS implants for large snakes, such as ones offered by [https://www.telemetrysolutions.com Telemetry Solutions].
==Software== ===Embedded=== [[Duty Cycle]] Scheduling - GPS devices typically record data about the animal's exact location and store readings at pre-set intervals known as duty-cycles. By setting the interval between readings, the researcher is able to determine the lifespan of the device - very frequent readings drain battery power more rapidly, whereas longer intervals between readings might provide lower resolution but over a longer deployment.<ref>P. G. Ryan, S. L. Petersen, G. Peters and D. Grémillet, "GPS tracking a marine predator: the effects of precision, resolution and sampling rate on foraging tracks of African Penguins" in Marine Biology, International Journal on Life in Oceans and Coastal Waters, Volume 145, Number 2, August 2004, pp. 215-223 </ref>
Release Timers - Some devices can be programmed to drop off at a set time/date rather than requiring recapture and manually retrieval. Some may also be fitted with a low-power radio receiver allowing a remote signal to trigger the automatic release. {{Citation needed|date=January 2008}}
===Analytical=== Locational data provided by GPS devices can be displayed using GIS packages such as the [[open-source]] [[GRASS GIS|GRASS]] or plotted and prepared for display on the World Wide Web using packages such as [[Generic Mapping Tools|Generic Mapping Tools (GMT)]], [https://github.com/PnEcrins/FollowDem FollowDem] (developed by Ecrins national Park to track ibex) or [http://www.seaturtle.org/maptool/ Maptool].
Statistical software such as [[R (programming language)|R]] can be used to display and examine data and may reveal behavioural patterns or trends.
==Data retrieval== ===Argos=== GPS tracking devices have been linked to an Argos Platform Transmitter Terminal (PTT) enabling them to transmit data via the [[Argos System]], a scientific satellite system which has been in use since 1978. Users can download their data directly from Argos via [[telnet]] and process the raw data to extract their transmitted information.<ref>FANCY, S. G., L. F. PANK, D. C. DOUGLAS, C. H. CURBY, G. W. GARNER, S. C. AMSTR AND W. L. REGELIN. 1988. Satellite telemetry: A new tool for wildlife research and management. US. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Publication 172. 54 pp.</ref>
Where satellite uplink fails due to antenna damage, it may be possible to intercept the underpowered transmission locally using a satellite uplink receiver.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/6159767.stm BBC NEWS | Technology | Snow Leopard Diary<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===GSM=== GPS location data can be transmitted via the [[GSM]] mobile/cell phone network, using [[SMS]] messages or [[internet protocols]] over a [[GPRS]] session.<ref>Mcconnell et al., (2004) "Phoning Home - A New GSM Mobile Phone Telemetry System To Collect Mark-Recapture Data", ''Marine Mammal Science'' 20 (2), pp.274–283</ref>. The [http://www.EPASTO.eu EPASTO] GPS is dedicated to follow and locate cow.
===UHF/VHF=== GPS data may be transmitted via short-range radio signals and decoded using a custom receiver.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}}

It is also popular among the [[Tamil diaspora]] in [[Sri Lanka]], [[Malaysia]] and [[Singapore]] .<ref name="FL_2002">[http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl1919/19190910.htm Promise and potential] by T.S.Subramanian. ''Frontline'', Volume 19 - Issue 19, September 14 - 27, 2002.</ref><ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/arts/survivors-of-time-the-bell-still-tolls/article2221434.ece Survivors of time - The bell still tolls]</ref>
The brand is manufactured by the [[Madurai]]-based S.P.S. Jayam and Company. It is prepared with a combination of [[herbs]].<ref name="FL_2002"/> The trademark "Gopal Tooth Powder" was first registered on 30 April 1947.<ref>[http://www.the-laws.com/Encyclopedia/Browse/Case?CaseId=210891642000 S.P.S. Selvaraj V/S V. Muthusamy Naicker]</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=[[CCH (company)|CCH Incorporated]] |title=Intellectual Property Rights Case Digest |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vRY9AQAAIAAJ |year=2008 |publisher=CCH India |isbn=978-90-411-3158-4 | page=398 }}</ref>

{{wiktionary|handle}} A '''handle''' is a part of, or attachment to, an object that can be moved or used by hand. The design of each type of handle involves substantial [[ergonomics|ergonomic]] issues, even where these are dealt with intuitively or by following tradition. Handles for [[tools]] are an important part of their function, enabling the user to exploit the tools to maximum effect. [[Package handle]]s allow for convenient carrying of packages. [[File:Claw-hammer.jpg|275px|thumb|A modern claw hammer with [[rubber]] handle]]
== General design criteria == [[Image:Tool-pliers.jpg|thumb|Flat-nose pliers with [[thermoplastic]] handles]] The three nearly universal requirements of are: # Sufficient strength to support the object, or to otherwise transmit the force involved in the task the handle serves. # Sufficient length to permit the hand or hands gripping it to reliably exert that force. # Sufficiently small [[circumference]] to permit the hand or hands to surround it far enough to grip it as solidly as needed to exert that force.
== Specific needs == Other requirements may apply to specific handles: * A sheath or coating on the handle that provides [[friction]] against the hand, reducing the gripping force needed to achieve a reliable grip. * Designs such as recessed car-door handles, reducing the chance of accidental operation, or simply the inconvenience of "snagging" the handle. * Sufficient circumference to distribute the force comfortably and safely over the hand. An example where this requirement is almost the sole purpose for a handle's existence is the handle that consists of two pieces: a hollow wooden cylinder about the diameter of a finger and a bit longer than one hand-width, and a stiff wire that passes through the center of the cylinder, has two right angles, and is shaped into a hook at each end. This handle permits comfortable carrying, with otherwise bare hands, of a heavy package, suspended on a tight string that passes around the top and bottom of it: the string is strong enough to support it, but the pressure the string would exert on fingers that grasped it directly would often be unacceptable. * Design to thwart unwanted access, for example, by children or thieves. In these cases many of the other requirements may have reduced importance. For example, a child-proof doorknob can be difficult for even an adult to use.
==Pull handles== [[Image:Drawer handle.jpg|thumb|Many drawers use pull handles.]] One major category of handles are ''pull'' handles, where one or more hands grip the handle or handles, and exert force to shorten the distance between the hands and their corresponding shoulders. The three criteria stated above are universal for pull handles.
Many pull handles are for lifting, mostly on objects to be carried.
Horizontal pull handles are widespread, including [[drawer pull]]s, handles on latchless doors and the outside of car doors. The inside controls for opening car doors from inside are usually pull handles, although their function of permitting the door to be ''pushed'' open is accomplished by an internal unlatching linkage.
Pull handles are also a frequent host of common [[Door Handle Bacteria|door handle bacteria]] such as [[Escherichia coli|e-coli]], fungal or other viral infections.<ref>[http://www.healthywaukesha.com/door-handles-can-spread-germs Door Handles Can Spread Germs] retrieved November 2016</ref>
Two kinds of pull handles may involve motion in addition to the hand-focused motions described: * Pulling the starting cord on a small internal-combustion engine may, besides moving the hand toward the shoulder, also exploit simultaneously pushing a wheeled vehicle away with the other hand, stepping away from the engine, and/or standing from a squat. * Some throwing motions, as in a [[track and field|track-and-field]] [[hammer throw]], involve pulling on a handle against centrifugal force (without bringing it closer), in the course of accelerating the thrown object by forcing it into circular motion.
==Twist handles== [[Image:Door handle.jpg|thumb|Many doors use twist handles.]] Another category of hand-operated device requires grasping (but not pulling) and rotating the hand and either the lower arm or the whole arm, about their axis. When the grip required is a fist grip, as with a [[door handle]] that has an arm rather than a knob to twist, the term "handle" unambiguously applies. Another clear case is a rarer device seen on mechanically complicated doors like those of airliners, where (instead of the whole hand moving down as it also rotates, on the door handles just described) the axis of rotation is between the thumb and the outermost fingers, so the thumb moves up if the outer fingers move down.
==Handles for wide-range motion== The handles of [[bicycle|bicycle grip]]s, [[club (weapon)|club-style weapon]]s, [[shovel]]s and spades, [[axe]]s, [[hammer]]s, mallets and [[hatchet]]s, [[baseball bat]]s, [[racquet|racket]]s, [[golf club (equipment)|golf club]]s, and [[croquet]] mallets involve a greater range of [[ergonomic]] issues.

'''Hydrothermal liquefaction''' (HTL) is a [[thermal depolymerization]] process used to convert wet [[biomass]] into crude-like oil -sometimes referred to as [[Biofuel|bio-oil]] or biocrude- under moderate temperature and high pressure.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|title = A review on process conditions for optimum bio-oil yield in hydrothermal liquefaction of biomass|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1364032110004235|journal = Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews|date = 2011-04-01|pages = 1615–1624|volume = 15|issue = 3|doi = 10.1016/j.rser.2010.11.054|first = Javaid|last = Akhtar|first2 = Nor Aishah Saidina|last2 = Amin}}</ref> The crude-like oil (or bio-oil) has high [[energy density]] with a [[Heat of combustion|lower heating value]] of 33.8-36.9 MJ/kg and 5-20 wt% oxygen and renewable chemicals.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Historical Developments in Hydroprocessing Bio-oils|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ef070044u|journal = Energy & Fuels|date = 2007-05-01|issn = 0887-0624|pages = 1792–1815|volume = 21|issue = 3|doi = 10.1021/ef070044u|first = Douglas C.|last = Elliott}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Liquid fuels from biomass via a hydrothermal process|url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/000925099080164A|journal = Chemical Engineering Science|date = 1990-01-01|volume = 45|issue = 8|doi = 10.1016/0009-2509(90)80164-a|first = F.|last = Goudriaan|first2 = D.G.R.|last2 = Peferoen}}</ref>
The reaction usually involves homogeneous and/or heterogeneous [[Catalysis|catalysts]] to improve the quality of products and yields.<ref name=":2" /> Carbon and hydrogen of an organic material, such as biomass, peat or low-ranked coals (lignite) are thermo-chemically converted into hydrophobic compounds with low viscosity and high solubility. Depending on the processing conditions, the fuel can be used as produced for heavy engines, including marine and rail or upgraded to transportation fuels,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ramirez|first1=Jerome|last2=Brown|first2=Richard|last3=Rainey|first3=Thomas|title=A Review of Hydrothermal Liquefaction Bio-Crude Properties and Prospects for Upgrading to Transportation Fuels|journal=Energies|date=1 July 2015|volume=8|issue=7|page=6765|doi=10.3390/en8076765|url=http://www.mdpi.com/1996-1073/8/7/6765}}</ref> such as diesel, gasoline or jet-fuels.
== History == As early as the 1920s, the concept of using hot water and alkali catalysts to produce oil out of biomass was proposed.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|title = Production of Oil from Plant Material|url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/99/2573/309|journal = Science|date = 1944-04-21|issn = 0036-8075|pmid = 17737216|pages = 309–312|volume = 99|issue = 2573|doi = 10.1126/science.99.2573.309|first = E.|last = Berl|bibcode = 1944Sci....99..309B}}</ref> This was the foundation of later HTL technologies that attracted research interest especially during the 1970s oil embargo. It was around that time that a high-pressure (hydrothermal) liquefaction process was developed at the Pittsburgh Energy Research Center (PERC) and later demonstrated (at the 100 kg/h scale) at the Albany Biomass Liquefaction Experimental Facility at Albany, Oregon, US.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="ToorReview" /> In 1982, Shell Oil developed the HTU™ process in the Netherlands.<ref name="ToorReview" /> Other organizations that have previously demonstrated HTL of biomass include Hochschule für Angewandte Wissenschaften Hamburg, Germany, SCF Technologies in Copenhagen, Denmark, EPA’s Water Engineering Research Laboratory, Cincinnati, Ohio, USA, and Changing World Technology Inc. (CWT), Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA.<ref name="ToorReview" /> Today, technology companies such as [http://www.licella.com.au Licella/Ignite Energy Resources] (Australia), [http://www.altacaenerji.com/en/ Altaca Energy] (Turkey), [http://steeperenergy.com/ Steeper Energy] (Denmark, Canada), and [http://nabrosenergy.in/ Nabros Energy] (India) continue to explore the commercialization of HTL.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://task39.org/files/2014/01/Task-39-Drop-in-Biofuels-Report-FINAL-2-Oct-2014-ecopy.pdf|title = The Potential and Challenges of Drop-in Biofuels|date = July 2014|accessdate = 3 Sep 2015|website = |publisher = A report by IEA Bioenergy Task 39|author1=Sergios Karatzos |author2=James D. McMillan |author3=Jack N. Saddler }}</ref>
== Chemical reactions == In hydrothermal liquefaction processes, long carbon chain molecules in biomass are thermally cracked and oxygen is removed in the form of H<sub>2</sub>O (dehydration) and CO<sub>2</sub> (decarboxylation). These reactions result in the production of high H/C ratio bio-oil. Simplified descriptions of dehydration and decarboxylation reactions can be found in the literature (e.g. Asghari and Yoshida (2006)<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Dehydration of fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural in sub-critical water over heterogeneous zirconium phosphate catalysts|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0008621506003363|journal = Carbohydrate Research|date = 2006-10-16|pages = 2379–2387|volume = 341|issue = 14|doi = 10.1016/j.carres.2006.06.025|first = Feridoun Salak|last = Asghari|first2 = Hiroyuki|last2 = Yoshida}}</ref> and Snåre et al. (2007)<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Production of diesel fuel from renewable feeds: Kinetics of ethyl stearate decarboxylation|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1385894707002197|journal = Chemical Engineering Journal|date = 2007-11-01|pages = 29–34|volume = 134|series = Proceedings of the XVII International Conference on Chemical Reactors CHEMREACTOR-17 and Post-Symposium "Catalytic Processing of Renewable Sources: Fuel, Energy, Chemicals"CR-17 Special IssueProf. Alexander S. Noskov|issue = 1–3|doi = 10.1016/j.cej.2007.03.064|first = M.|last = Snåre|first2 = I.|last2 = Kubičková|first3 = P.|last3 = Mäki-Arvela|first4 = K.|last4 = Eränen|first5 = J.|last5 = Wärnå|first6 = D. Yu.|last6 = Murzin}}</ref>)
==Process== Most applications of hydrothermal liquefaction operate at temperatures between 250-550<sup>o</sup>C and high pressures of 5-25 MPa as well as catalysts for 20–60 minutes,<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> although higher or lower temperatures can be used to optimize gas or liquid yields, respectively.<ref name="ToorReview">{{cite journal|last1=Toor|first1=Saqib Sohail|last2=Rosendahl|first2=Lasse|last3=Rudolf|first3=Andreas|title=Hydrothermal liquefaction of biomass: A review of subcritical water technologies|journal=Energy|date=May 2011|volume=36|pages=2328–2342|doi=10.1016/j.energy.2011.03.013}}</ref> At these temperatures and pressures, the water present in the biomass becomes either subcritical or supercritical, depending on the conditions, and acts as a solvent, reactant, and catalyst to facilitate the reaction of biomass to bio-oil.
The exact conversion of biomass to bio-oil is dependent on several variables:<ref name=":2" /> * Feedstock composition * Temperature and heating rate * Pressure * Solvent * Residence time * Catalysts
===Feedstock===
Theoretically, any biomass can be converted into bio-oil using hydrothermal liquefaction regardless of water content, and various different biomasses have been tested, from forestry and agriculture residues<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kosinkova|first1=Jana|last2=Ramirez|first2=Jerome|last3=Jablonsky|first3=Michal|last4=Ristovski|first4=Zoran|last5=Brown|first5=Richard|last6=Rainey|first6=Thomas|title=Energy and chemical conversion of five Australian lignocellulosic feedstocks into bio-crude through liquefaction|journal=RSC Advances|date=24 May 2017|volume=7|issue=44|page=27707-27717|doi=10.1039/C7RA02335A|url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/Content/ArticleLanding/2017/RA/C7RA02335A}}</ref>, sewage sludges, food process wastes, to emerging non-food biomass such as algae.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name="ToorReview"/> The composition of cellulose, hemicellulose, protein, and lignin in the feedstock influence the yield and quality of the oil from the process.
===Temperature and Heating Rate=== Temperature plays a major role in the conversion of biomass to bio-oil. The temperature of the reaction determines the depolymerization of the biomass to bio-oil, as well as the repolymerization into char.<ref name=":2" /> While the ideal reaction temperature is dependent on the feedstock used, temperatures above ideal lead to an increase in char formation and eventually increased gas formation, while lower than ideal temperatures reduce depolymerization and overall product yields.
Similarly to temperature, the rate of heating plays a critical role in the production of the different phase streams, due to the prevalence of secondary reactions at non-optimum heating rates.<ref name=":2" /> Secondary reactions become dominant in heating rates that are too low, leading to the formation of char. While high heating rates are required to form liquid bio-oil, there is a threshold heating rate and temperature where liquid production is inhibited and gas production is favored in secondary reactions.
===Pressure=== Pressure (along with temperature) determines the super- or subcritical state of solvents as well as overall reaction kinetics and the energy inputs required to yield the desirable HTL products (oil, gas, chemicals, char etc.).<ref name=":2" />
===Residence Time=== Hydrothermal liquefaction is a fast process, resulting in low residence times for depolymerization to occur. Typical residence times are measured in minutes (15 to 60 minutes); however, the residence time is highly dependent on the reaction conditions, including feedstock, solvent ratio and temperature. As such, optimization of the residence time is necessary to ensure a complete depolymerizaiton without allowing further reactions to occur.<ref name=":2" />
===Catalysts=== While water acts as a catalyst in the reaction, other catalysts can be added to the reaction vessel to optimize the conversion.<ref name="DuanCatalyst">{{cite journal|last1=Duan|first1=Peigao|last2=Savage|first2=Phillip E.|title=Hydrothermal Liquefaction of a Microalga with Heterogeneous Catalysts|journal=Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research|date=2011|volume=50|pages=52–61|doi=10.1021/ie100758s}}</ref> Previously used catalysts include water-soluble inorganic compounds and salts, including KOH and Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>, as well as transition metal catalysts using [[Nickel|Ni]], [[Palladium|Pd]], [[Platinum|Pt]], and [[Ruthenium|Ru]] supported on either [[carbon]], [[Silicon dioxide|silica]] or [[Aluminium oxide|alumina]]. The addition of these catalysts can lead to an oil yield increase of 20% or greater, due to the catalysts converting the protein, cellulose, and hemicellulose into oil. This ability for catalysts to convert biomaterials other than fats and oils to bio-oil allows for a wider range of feedstock to be used.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
==Environmental Impact== Biofuels that are produced through hydrothermal liquefaction are [[Carbon-neutral fuel|carbon neutral]], meaning that there are no net carbon emissions produced when burning the biofuel. The plant materials used to produce bio-oils use photosynthesis to grow, and as such consume carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. The burning of the biofuels produced releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, but is nearly completely offset by the carbon dioxide consumed from growing the plants, resulting in a release of only 15-18 g of CO<sub>2</sub>/kWh or energy produced. This is substantially lower than the releases rate of fossil fuel technologies, which can range from releases of 955 g/kWh (coal), 813 g/kWh (oil), and 446 g/kWh (natural gas).<ref name=":2" /> Recently, Steeper Energy announced that the [[Emission intensity|Carbon Intensity (CI)]] of its Hydrofaction™ oil is 15 CO<sub>2</sub>eq/MJ according to [http://www.ghgenius.ca/ GHGenius model] (version 4.03a), while diesel fuel is 93.55 CO<sub>2</sub>eq/MJ.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://steeperenergy.com/news/milestones-and-activities|title = Milestones & Activities|date = Q3 2015|accessdate = 3 Sep 2015|website = |publisher = |last = Steeper Energy}}</ref>
Hydrothermal liquefaction is a clean process that doesn't produce harmful compounds, such as ammonia, NO<sub>x</sub>, or SO<sub>x</sub>.<ref name=":2" /> Instead the [[heteroatom]]s, including nitrogen, sulfur, and chlorine, are converted into harmless byproducts such as N<sub>2</sub> and inorganic acids that can be neutralized with bases.
==Compare with Pyrolysis and other [[Biomass to liquid|BtL]] technologies== The HTL process differs from [[pyrolysis]] as it can process wet biomass and produce a bio-oil that contains approximately twice the energy density of pyrolysis oil. Pyrolysis is a related process to HTL, but biomass must be processed and dried in order to increase the yield.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bridgwater|first1=A.V|last2=Peacocke|first2=G.V.C|title=Fast pyrolysis processes for biomass|journal=Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews|date=March 2000|volume=4|pages=1–73|doi=10.1016/s1364-0321(99)00007-6}}</ref> The presence of water in pyrolysis drastically increases the heat of vaporization of the organic material, increasing the energy required to decompose the biomass. Typical pyrolysis processes require a water content of less than 40% to suitably convert the biomass to bio-oil. This requires considerable pretreatment of wet biomass such as tropical grasses, which contain a water content as high as 80-85%, and even further treatment for aquatic species, which can contain higher than 90% water content.<ref name=":2" />
The HTL oil can contain up to 80% of the feedstock carbon content (single pass).<ref name=":4" /> HTL oil has good potential to yield bio-oil with "drop-in" properties that can be directly distributed in existing petroleum infrastructure.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = Hydrothermal liquefaction of biomass: A review of subcritical water technologies|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0360544211001691|journal = Energy|date = 2011-05-01|pages = 2328–2342|volume = 36|issue = 5|doi = 10.1016/j.energy.2011.03.013|first = Saqib Sohail|last = Toor|first2 = Lasse|last2 = Rosendahl|first3 = Andreas|last3 = Rudolf}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2013-02/au-hl020613.php|title = Hydrothermal liquefaction -- the most promising path to a sustainable bio-oil production|last = AARHUS UNIVERSITY|first = |date = 6 Feb 2013|work = |access-date = 3 Sep 2015|via = http://www.eurekalert.org/}}</ref>
